text.24:
In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh heard Moses' words and saw his convincing demeanor and his sincerity in conveying the da'wah, especially concerning tawhid, which was that Pharaoh and his people should worship the One God who created them, Pharaoh rose up in opposition. He asked in an angry tone, "O Moses, you claim to be a messenger of the Lord of the worlds. What is the Lord of the worlds?" Pharaoh was very surprised and felt offended by Moses' acknowledgment of Allah's power and oneness because he had proclaimed to his people that he was the only god, there is no god besides him, as Allah explained in His word:

And Pharaoh said, "O eminent ones, I do not know of any god for you other than me." (al-Qasas/28: 38)

(24) In this verse, Allah explains Moses' answer to Pharaoh's question about the God that Moses acknowledged as the God who sent him. To facilitate Pharaoh's understanding of what was being asked, Moses explained some of the attributes that demonstrate the power of the Lord of all the worlds, in accordance with the intent of Pharaoh's question. Moses said that the God who sent him is the God who created the heavens and the earth and everything in between in the best possible way. The God who made the sun, moon, glittering stars in the sky, rivers, seas, mountains, trees, animals, plants on earth, wind, air, and everything else that is between the heavens and the earth. If Pharaoh and his people were indeed level-headed, of sound mind, and had open hearts, then with Moses' answer, they would certainly believe and be convinced of the oneness of Allah who sent Moses.
text.25: This verse explains Pharaoh's reaction to Moses' answer above. After hearing Moses' answer, he quickly turned to his people who were around him, and displayed his astonishment. Pharaoh said to them in a mocking and sarcastic tone, "O my people, have you all heard Moses' words saying that there is a God besides me? Isn't that a strange thing and a deviation?" Pharaoh did this because he was worried that his people would be influenced by Moses' answer. If that were the case, they would turn away from believing in him and acknowledging him as God.
text.26:
Moses saw that Pharaoh and his people were still not satisfied with his answer, so they were still unwilling to acknowledge and believe that the one who sent Moses was the Lord of all the worlds. Moses then added to his explanation, hoping that with this additional explanation, they would realize and become aware of their misguided stance.

Moses said that the Lord who sent him was the Lord of Pharaoh and his ancestors of old. Moses shifted their focus to an important point, namely that the true Lord is the Lord who created them, their ancestors, and Pharaoh. With this realization, they would think that they and this universe exist because there is a Creator and someone who governs it, having the power to do as He wills. The Lord of the universe is the one who governs it, that is, the true Lord who remains and exists, even if all His creatures no longer exist, and He is *Qadim* (eternal) without beginning. He is also the Lord who sent Moses.
text.27: After Musa explained the proofs of Allah's divinity who sent him, Pharaoh was rendered speechless, unable to provide an answer. He then uttered words directed at his people to make them doubt the reasons and proofs that Prophet Musa had presented. Pharaoh said, "O my people. Indeed, the messenger who claims that he is sent to you all is actually a madman. He utters words that cannot be understood or comprehended at all because he says that there is a God besides me."
text.28: In this verse, Moses presents again the attributes of the Lord of all the worlds who sent him. He is the Lord who controls the east and the west and what is between them. He is the Lord who made the east the place where the sun rises, and the west the place where the sun sets. He is also the One who made the journey of the stars in a regular orbit. For those who want to use their minds, they can certainly understand that such events are clear evidence that shows the existence of a Lord who arranges everything neatly and very well. Moses initially faced and answered Pharaoh's question with a gentle tone and firm words: "if you use your mind." That utterance was appropriate to reject Pharaoh's accusation against him that he was insane.
text.29: In this verse, Allah recounts that when Pharaoh was unable to refute the explanations and proofs presented by Moses to him, he then acted harshly and threatened Moses. Pharaoh said, "O Moses, if you dare to worship a god other than me, then I will put you in prison. There you will feel a very painful torment, cruel treatment, and no mercy whatsoever." The torment suffered by those imprisoned by Pharaoh was more severe than murder, because he imprisoned a person until they died.
text.30: In this verse, Allah explains that when Moses saw Pharaoh's treatment threatening his life, he was forced not to present the proofs that are normally acceptable to reason. He turned to miracles and extraordinary things. Moses said to Pharaoh, "O Pharaoh, will you imprison me even though I present clear proofs of the truth of my claim? That proof is the miracle that proves the existence of the Almighty God, and the truth of my prophethood."
text.31: In this verse, Allah explains that when Pharaoh heard the words of Prophet Musa, he said, "O Musa, if you are indeed truthful in your claim that you are a messenger, then bring us something manifest. Someone who claims to be a messenger certainly has proof to justify his claim." Pharaoh made this invitation because he was certain that Musa would not be able to fulfill his request.
text.32: In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh demanded that Moses bring forth clear proof of the truth of his da'wah (call to Islam), Moses immediately threw his staff, which suddenly transformed into a real serpent. It is mentioned in Tafsir ar-Razi that after Moses' staff turned into a serpent, the serpent leaped upwards, then descended back to the earth directly towards Pharaoh. Pharaoh said, "By the one who sent you, Moses, take the serpent, otherwise I myself will take it." Moses then took it, and the serpent returned to being a staff as before.
text.33: In this verse, Allah explains that after Moses finished showing clear evidence, Pharaoh said, "Are there any miracles besides that?" Moses answered, "Yes." Moses then put his hand into the opening of his garment, then took it out again. Suddenly, the hand shone, illuminating the surroundings, because of its very bright light. Ibn 'Abbas said, "When Moses took his hand out of his garment, suddenly the hand became white and luminous, illuminating the people who saw it, like the dazzling rays of the sun."
text.34: When Pharaoh saw and witnessed the proofs that Moses displayed, which demonstrated the truth of his message, he still denied and vehemently opposed Moses. He then presented three points to the leaders of his people. First, to reassure the hearts of the dignitaries and leaders around him, Pharaoh said to them, "Indeed, this Moses is truly a skilled magician, not a messenger of the Lord of all the worlds as he claims. What he displays is not a miracle, but merely magic."
text.35:
Secondly, to incite and instill hatred in the hearts of his nobles and leaders, so that they would not believe in Moses, Pharaoh said to them, "Indeed, the purpose of the magic that Moses displays is to win the hearts of the people. This aims to increase his supporters and followers in order to defeat you, the nobles and leaders. Ultimately, they will seize and expel you from your own land."

Thirdly, Pharaoh sought counsel, ideas, and suggestions from the nobles of his land and the leaders of his people, about what he should do, and how he should act to stem and thwart Moses's desires. Abu as-Su'ud, the author of *Tafsir Irsyad al-'Aql as-Salim ila Mazaya al-Kitab al-Karim*, considered Pharaoh's request to the nobles of his land to be a result of his confusion and astonishment in the face of the miracle that Moses had shown. This caused Pharaoh to change his attitude in three ways that demeaned his dignity and lowered his position:
text.36: In this verse, Allah explains the response of the leaders and chiefs of Pharaoh's people to the advice he requested. They suggested that the matter of Musa and his brother, Harun, be postponed because they would gather all the skilled magicians in their land. These magicians were gathered and ordered to come and hold a magic competition with Musa. On the day and at the place that had been determined, the magicians had to show their superiority in front of Pharaoh and Musa. According to them, at that time victory would be on their side so that the people would support him again. This suggestion was well received by Pharaoh and would be implemented in due course. In return, he would also fulfill all their demands.
text.37: In this verse, Allah explains the response of the chiefs and leaders of Pharaoh's people to the advice he sought. They suggested that the matter of Musa and his brother, Harun, be postponed because they would gather all the skilled magicians in their land. These magicians were gathered and ordered to come and hold a magic competition with Musa. On the day and at the place that had been determined, the magicians had to show their superiority before Pharaoh and Musa. According to them, at that time victory would be on their side so that the people would support him again. This advice was well received by Pharaoh and would be implemented in due course. In return, he would also fulfill all their demands.
text.38: In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh received advice from his chiefs and leaders not to act rashly against Moses, and that it would be better to gather the magicians, Pharaoh implemented that advice. He ordered that the magicians be ready at the appointed time, which was on a day announced as a festival day.
text.39: In these verses, Allah explains that Pharaoh ordered his people to gather, to witness the events that would take place on the day designated as a holiday. Pharaoh was confident that his side would be victorious. He believed that none of his people would believe in Musa (Moses). Pharaoh deliberately gathered all his people to witness the contest of strength between his magicians and Musa, so that they would continue to follow the magicians and adhere firmly to their religion.
text.40: In these verses, Allah explains that Pharaoh ordered his people to gather, to witness the events that would take place on the day designated as a festival day. Pharaoh was confident that his side would be victorious. He believed that none of his people would believe in Moses. Pharaoh deliberately gathered all his people to witness the contest of strength between his magicians and Moses, so that they would continue to follow the magicians and adhere firmly to their religion.
text.41: In these verses, Allah explains that after gathering in the room where Pharaoh was, the magicians asked Pharaoh for his wisdom in giving them payment and making them closer to him if they won. Pharaoh readily accepted this request, even promising to make them advisors who would always be invited to sit with him, and to make them among those closest to him. After a mutual understanding between the magicians and Pharaoh regarding payment and other facilities, they then competed in strength with Moses. They asked him, "O Moses! Will you be the first to present and demonstrate your magic, or will we be the first?"
text.42: In these verses, Allah explains that after gathering in the room where Pharaoh was, the magicians asked Pharaoh for his wisdom in giving them payment and making them closer to him if they won later. Pharaoh accepted this request well, even promising to make them advisors who would always be invited to sit with him, and made them among those closest to him. After there was a mutual understanding between the magicians and Pharaoh regarding payment and other facilities, they then competed in strength with Moses. They asked him, "O Moses! Will you be the first to present and demonstrate your magic, or will we be the first?"
text.43:
This verse depicts the atmosphere of a power struggle between Pharaoh's magicians and the miracle of Prophet Musa (Moses). Musa offered the magicians to begin their magic, which they believed could nullify Musa's claim as a messenger of Allah. Pharaoh's magicians immediately threw the ropes they had prepared while invoking Pharaoh's name, and they felt confident of winning. With the speed of their hand movements and their magic, the ropes seemed to move, deceiving the people who witnessed it, so they thought the ropes had turned into real snakes, crawling here and there. This is described in Allah's word:

"Then suddenly their ropes and staffs appeared to him as though they were moving swiftly because of their magic." (Taha/20: 66)

With their magic, the magicians had frightened and deceived the eyes of the people. They exerted all their abilities, and considered it sufficient to gain victory in the power struggle.
text.44:
This verse depicts the atmosphere of a power struggle between Pharaoh's magicians and the miracle of Prophet Musa (Moses). Musa offered the magicians to begin their magic, which they believed could nullify Musa's claim as a messenger of Allah. Pharaoh's magicians immediately threw the ropes they had prepared while invoking Pharaoh's name, and they felt confident of winning. With the speed of their hand movements and their magic, the ropes seemed to move, deceiving the people who witnessed it, so they thought the ropes had turned into real snakes, crawling here and there. This is described in Allah's word:

"Then suddenly their ropes and staffs appeared to him as though they were moving swiftly because of their magic." (Taha/20: 66)

With their magic, the magicians had frightened and deceived the eyes of the crowd. They exerted all their abilities, and considered it sufficient to gain victory in the power struggle.
text.45:
After all of Pharaoh's magicians threw their ropes and staffs, which in the eyes of the crowd seemed to become snakes, it was Musa's turn. When Musa dropped his staff, which transformed into a real snake, suddenly that snake devoured all the false snakes that they had fabricated. Thus, it became clear which was true and which was false, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"So the truth was established, and what they were doing was shown to be vain." (al-A'raf/7: 118)

And His word:

"Rather, We hurl the truth [i.e., the Qur'an] against falsehood, and it obliterates it, and thereupon it departs." (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)
text.46:
After all of Pharaoh's magicians threw their ropes and staffs, which in the eyes of the crowd seemed to become snakes, it was Moses' turn. When Moses dropped his staff, which transformed into a real snake, suddenly that snake devoured all the false snakes they had created. Thus, it became clear which was true and which was false, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"So the truth was established, and all that they did was in vain." (al-A'raf/7: 118)

And His word:

"Rather, We dash the truth upon falsehood, and it destroys it, and thereupon it departs." (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)
text.47: In these verses, Allah explains that after witnessing what happened, Pharaoh's magicians surrendered. They fell prostrate and then prostrated to Allah, the Almighty and Most Powerful Lord, while declaring, "We have believed in the Lord of the universe, the Lord of Moses and Aaron." They did so because they realized that what they had shown to the people was merely illusion and deception. As for what Moses showed, it was a miracle, and truly not magic. It was a power far superior to what they knew, and it came from the heavens to strengthen Moses in his claim as a messenger of Allah.
text.48: In these verses, Allah explains that after witnessing what happened, Pharaoh's magicians surrendered. They fell prostrate and then prostrated to Allah, the Almighty and Most Powerful Lord, while declaring, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds, the Lord of Moses and Aaron." They did so because they realized that what they had shown to the people was merely illusion and deception. As for what Moses showed, it was a miracle, and certainly not magic. It was a power far superior to what they knew, and it came from the heavens to strengthen Moses in his claim as a messenger of Allah.
text.49:
After the magicians declared that they had become believers in the Lord of the Universe, which meant they no longer acknowledged Pharaoh as their god, Pharaoh became very angry. Arrogantly, he threatened to punish them, but the threat was ignored by them. Even with that threat, their faith became even more steadfast because the veil of disbelief had been lifted and the light of truth had become clearly visible to them.

The declaration uttered by the magicians made Pharaoh feel that his rights as a ruler and one who proclaimed himself a god had been violated, because they had believed in Moses without asking his permission first. According to Pharaoh, before they embraced the religion of Moses, they should have asked his permission first, because he was a ruler who must be obeyed. To deceive and mislead the masses, Pharaoh accused Moses and the magicians of conspiring, because Moses had taught them magic. This accusation was certainly unfounded, because before the contest of strength, they had not met with Moses. The peak of Pharaoh's anger was that he threatened them with torture as a result of their actions. He threatened to cut off their hands and feet on opposite sides and even kill them.
text.50:
Pharaoh's rather severe threat was completely ignored by the magicians. They even hoped to experience that threat because, for them, everyone who lives at some point will die, and there is no way to escape it. Allah says:

"Every soul will taste death." (al-Anbiya'/21: 35)

And His saying:

"Say, "Indeed, the death from which you flee - indeed, it will meet you." (al-Jumu'ah/62: 8)

They only thought about two things, as a comfort to their hearts:

First, they would return to the teachings of the Lord of the universe, the God worshipped by Moses and Aaron, and follow the religion of the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him). Thus, they would be saved from the extremely painful and prolonged torment of the Hereafter, which is far more severe than the punishment that Pharaoh threatened them with.

Second, they greatly hoped that the Lord of the universe would forgive their sins for practicing magic and disbelief. They were the first to believe in the God worshipped by Moses, from among the many people who witnessed the contest of power.
text.51:
Pharaoh's rather severe threat was completely ignored by the magicians. They even hoped to experience that threat because, for them, everyone who lives at some point will die; there is no way to escape it. Allah says:

"Every soul will taste death." (al-Anbiya'/21: 35)

And He says:

"Say, "Indeed, the death from which you flee - indeed, it will meet you." (al-Jumu'ah/62: 8)

They only thought about two things, as a comfort to their hearts:

First, they would return to the teachings of the Lord of the universe, the God worshipped by Moses and Aaron, and follow the religion of the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him). Thus, they would be saved from the extremely painful and prolonged torment of the Hereafter, which is far more severe than the punishment that Pharaoh threatened them with.

Second, they earnestly hoped that the Lord of the universe would forgive their sins for practicing magic and disbelief. They were the first to believe in the God worshipped by Moses, from among the many people who witnessed the contest of strength.
text.52: This verse explains that Allah revealed to Moses to leave Egypt with the Children of Israel at night. Allah also informed him that when Pharaoh heard this news, he and his army would surely pursue them and force them to return to being slaves who served their desires and needs. The departure of the Children of Israel would cause them great loss.
text.53: This verse explains that when Pharaoh learned that Moses and the Children of Israel had departed, he then dispatched some of his officials to all parts of Egypt. He also gathered his army to pursue Moses and the Children of Israel, return them to Egypt, and inflict severe torment upon them. To boost the morale and encourage his soldiers, Pharaoh stated that the task they had to carry out was easy to accomplish because Moses and the Children of Israel were very few in number. Therefore, they should not hesitate. Easily and in a relatively short time, they would be able to overtake Moses and his group and bring them back.
text.54: This verse explains that when Pharaoh learned that Moses and the Children of Israel had departed, he then dispatched some of his officials to all parts of Egypt. He also gathered his army to pursue Moses and the Children of Israel, return them to Egypt, and inflict severe torment upon them. To boost the morale and encourage his soldiers, Pharaoh stated that the task they had to carry out was easy to accomplish because Moses and the Children of Israel were very few in number. Therefore, they did not need to hesitate. Easily and in a relatively short time, they would be able to overtake Moses and his group and bring them back.
text.55: Pharaoh sought reasons to antagonize the Children of Israel by saying that they were enemies who were always causing chaos, making security uncertain. The Children of Israel were also said to constantly provoke anger, embrace a new religion, and abandon the religion of their ancestors. They dared to leave Egypt without first asking permission, taking away the possessions they had borrowed from Pharaoh and his people. Pharaoh told his people to always be careful and vigilant to ensure that their actions did not have far-reaching consequences. They had sufficient and complete weaponry to defeat the Children of Israel.
text.56: Pharaoh sought reasons to antagonize the Children of Israel by saying that they were enemies who were always causing chaos, making security uncertain. The Children of Israel were also said to be constantly provoking anger, embracing a new religion, and abandoning the religion of their ancestors. They dared to leave Egypt without first asking permission, taking away the possessions they had borrowed from Pharaoh and his people. Pharaoh told his people to always be careful and vigilant to ensure that their actions did not have far-reaching consequences. They had sufficient and complete weaponry to defeat the Children of Israel.
text.57: This verse explains that Allah will bring Pharaoh and his people out of pleasure and into hardship and destruction. They will leave behind luxurious and towering houses, leaving behind beautiful gardens where they could freely enjoy themselves. They will also leave behind rivers that flow clearly, such as the Nile River, which was a part of their lives.
text.58:
Allah explains that Pharaoh and his people would leave behind possessions, kingdoms, and high and noble positions that were unparalleled. Ibn Umar, Ibn 'Abbas, and Mujahid stated that what is meant by noble positions here are the pulpits for Pharaoh's dignitaries.

Some commentators differ in opinion regarding these high positions. Some are of the opinion that they are beautiful houses, and some are of the opinion that they are the pulpits and palaces of Pharaoh's dignitaries. Allah says:

"How many gardens and springs did they leave behind, and fields and noble dwellings, and comforts in which they rejoiced." (ad-Dukhan/44: 25-27)
text.59:
This verse explains that all the gardens and beautiful places, rivers, wealth, and high positions that Pharaoh and his people would leave behind, would be bestowed upon the Children of Israel in Palestine in accordance with Allah's promise to them. Allah says:

"And We caused the people who had been oppressed to inherit the eastern regions of the land and the western ones, which We had blessed. And the good word of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of what they had patiently endured. And We destroyed [all] that Pharaoh and his people were producing and what they had been building." (al-A'raf/7: 137)
text.60:
This verse explains that Pharaoh, along with all his government officials and soldiers, were only able to leave Egypt to pursue Moses and the Children of Israel in the morning. Regarding their delay, there are two opinions:

First: As mentioned in the Old Testament (Exodus 11-12), they were struck by the plague of death on the night Moses and the Children of Israel left Egypt. In the middle of the night, many Egyptian firstborns died, both human and animal, causing them to be busy burying the corpses until morning. Second: Because on that night they were enveloped in a thick fog and very cold air until morning.
text.61: When Moses, along with the Children of Israel, and Pharaoh with his army were within close proximity, the Children of Israel felt anxious and worried that they would be overtaken by Pharaoh and his army. They said to Moses, "Pharaoh and his army have tormented our children before we departed, and after being overtaken, we will all be killed by them."
text.62: Regarding the anxiety and worry of the Children of Israel, Moses comforted them with a firm statement that they would certainly not be overtaken by Pharaoh. His action of inviting and leading the Children of Israel out of Egypt towards Palestine was a command and will of Allah. Thus, Allah would show them a way out, so that they would be safe from all threatening dangers. Allah would also give them help and victory and guarantee their safety from the cruelty of Pharaoh and his troops.
text.63:
This verse explains that Allah revealed to Moses and showed him a way out of the threatening danger. Moses was commanded to strike the sea with his staff so that the sea would split and form a path for all the descendants of the Children of Israel to pass through. Each split of the seawater was a large and high mountain, forming a dry path that the Children of Israel could traverse, as Allah says:

And We had revealed to Moses, "Set out by night with My servants and strike for them a dry path through the sea; you need not fear being overtaken [by Pharaoh] nor be afraid [of drowning]." (thaha/20: 77)
text.64: In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh saw the Children of Israel from close by walking across the sea, he and his army followed their tracks and entered the sea. When Pharaoh and his army were in the middle of the sea, while Musa (Moses) and the Children of Israel had already reached the other side of the sea and were all safe on land, the sea water closed back as usual. Thus, Pharaoh, who was treading the same path, was trapped by the water and drowned along with his army, so that not a single one of them survived.
text.65: In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh saw the Children of Israel from close by walking across the sea, he and his army followed their tracks and entered the sea. When Pharaoh and his army were in the middle of the sea, while Moses and the Children of Israel had already reached the other side and were all safe on land, the sea water returned to its normal state. Thus, Pharaoh, who was treading the same path, was trapped by the water and drowned along with his army, so that not a single one of them survived.
text.66: In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh saw the Children of Israel from close up walking across the sea, he and his army followed their tracks and entered the sea. When Pharaoh and his army were in the middle of the sea, while Moses and the Children of Israel had already reached the other side of the sea and were all safe on land, the sea water returned to its normal state. Thus, Pharaoh, who was treading the same path, was trapped by the water and drowned along with his army, so that not a single one of them survived.
text.67:
The success of Moses and all his followers in reaching the opposite shore safely, and the drowning of Pharaoh along with his entire army in the middle of the sea, is a clear sign of Allah's power and the truthfulness of Prophet Moses as His messenger. Allah always provides help and victory to His servants who believe sincerely. Allah also always destroys and punishes those who deny His verses, especially in the Hereafter. Allah says:

"Allah will surely help those who help Him (His cause). Indeed, Allah is Powerful, Almighty." (al-hajj/22: 40)

"That is the recompense of the enemies of Allah - the Fire. For them therein is the home of eternity as recompense for what they were denying Our verses." (Fussilat/41: 28)

People who are hard and whose hearts have hardened like Pharaoh and his people will not want to believe, even if they see the truth of something clearly. This event also becomes a comfort for the Messenger of Allah because with it, he knows that he is not the only one experiencing such trials, but also the previous prophets and messengers of Allah. Everything ends with victory for the prophets and messengers of Allah, and defeat for their enemies.
text.68: This verse explains that Allah is the All-Powerful and the All-Mighty. He will punish His enemies and the enemies of the prophets and messengers. However, Allah is the Most Merciful to the supporters and defenders of His religion.
text.69: Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to relate to the polytheists of Mecca the story of Prophet Ibrahim as a lesson for all his people. They were expected to emulate and take as an example the noble qualities that adorned the personality of Prophet Ibrahim. He was sincere in his deeds, had *tawakkul* (reliance on God), and constantly worshipped Allah, the One and Only. He was bestowed by Allah with intellectual intelligence from childhood as a gift worthy of being received by a messenger. This is what caused Ibrahim to always oppose his people (including his father) who worshipped idols which they treated as gods.
text.70: Ibrahim considered idol worship to be nonsensical. He asked his father and his people what their reason was for devoting themselves to gods that understood nothing. In reality, he was not unaware of the true nature of the idols they worshipped, but Ibrahim simply wanted to hear from their own mouths the concrete reasons for such worship. According to historians, their idols were made of gold and silver, and also of copper and iron. Therefore, they felt proud of the gods they had created. "What is the reason you deify these idols?" Ibrahim asked.
text.71: That question was answered by his people with arrogance, "Indeed, we are idol worshippers. We dedicate our entire lives and existence to them willingly." According to the commentators of the Quran (ahli tafsir), the people of Prophet Ibrahim only worshipped idols during the day. They were very diligent and devout in worshipping them.
text.72:
Hearing that explanation, Ibrahim became even more convinced that their belief was not based on reasonable grounds. He began to think about how to straighten out the misguided thinking of his people. His primary task was to return them to the teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism).

Ibrahim asked again whether those idols could hear the requests they uttered. He questioned this to test the extent to which their logic could be used to understand the words and actions in the form of prayers to the idols. Because if the object of worship itself could not hear, how could it grant the requests made to it? In essence, how could the essence of such worship be understood correctly if their minds could not properly comprehend the purpose of worshiping those idols?
text.73: Ibrahim's series of questions then continued with whether it was true that the gods they worshipped could bring benefit in life. Could they provide sustenance, food, and drink if they were truly almighty gods? Conversely, could they deliver their worshippers from calamities and misfortunes that befell them?
text.74: They answered those questions according to what they knew. However, in the end, Ibrahim understood the true motive behind that worship, which was a tradition inherited from their ancestors. "We only found our forefathers doing this, and that is the custom we follow," they answered Ibrahim firmly.
text.75: That answer did not satisfy him. The acts of *taqlid* without any basis had to be eradicated. The way to eradicate them was by making them aware of the error of their ways and those of their ancestors. Ibrahim reminded them whether it had never occurred to them and never crossed their minds to analyze and reflect on actions that were merely imitative.
text.76: In this verse, he affirms that they, or their ancestors, were people who refused to use their minds. Because it turns out that the idols they worshiped could not hear, let alone understand what was being asked of them. Moreover, these idols could not bring benefit or ward off harm. Their function is solely as man-made objects that should not be made into objects of worship.
text.77:
Then Prophet Ibrahim affirmed his stance. The stance of a messenger of God who carried the message to spread the understanding of *tauhid* (monotheism) among his people. He proclaimed himself the main enemy of their gods. According to him, the only one worthy of worship is God Almighty, the Lord of the universe. It is to Him that humans must devote themselves. This *tauhid* belief was based on several reasonable grounds.

The mission carried by Prophet Ibrahim was also carried by the previous prophet, namely Nuh. All the prophets and messengers carried such a fundamental task. In addition to inviting people to profess the oneness of Allah, they also openly opposed any form of worship that in principle associates partners with Allah. Prophet Nuh also opposed his people who intended to harm him because of his call to believe, as depicted in Allah's word:

Therefore, resolve upon your plan, you and your partners, and let not your plan be obscure to you. Then execute it upon me and give me no respite. (Yunus/10: 71)

Likewise, Allah's word explains the words of Prophet Hud a.s.:

He (Hud) said, "Indeed, I call Allah to witness, and witness [yourselves] that I am disassociated from whatever you associate [with Him]. (Hud/11: 54)
text.78:
In the following verses, Prophet Ibrahim explains some of the proofs of the Oneness of God, which are part of the attributes of Allah Rabbul 'alamin (Lord of the Worlds). Allah is the creator of mankind, with the best of creation. He is also the one who gives guidance (hidayah).

As is known, hidayah is of various kinds. There is hidayah that is called hidayah of the five senses, hidayah of reason (mind), hidayah of instinct (intelligence brought from birth), and hidayah of religion (ad-din). Reason is a very valuable hidayah from God, because with reason humans are able to distinguish between bad and good. Reason also distinguishes humans from animals.

However, reason alone is not a guarantee for human salvation. Therefore, Allah completes His blessings by giving them religion. Hidayah of religion is only given by God. If someone is willed by Allah to obtain hidayah (religion), no one can prevent it. Conversely, if Allah has not willed it, no one can give guidance. Even the prophets and messengers themselves who are assigned to bring hidayah also do not have the authority to give hidayah, as seen in the story of Prophet Ibrahim in another verse (Surah al-An'am/6: 74-88) which tells the dialogue between him and his father (Azar) and his people. Ibrahim tried to convert his father to Islam, but Allah did not give hidayah, so he remained in polytheism.

Similarly, the uncle of Prophet Muhammad, Abu Thalib, who had contributed greatly to developing the Prophet's da'wah in Mecca. The Prophet greatly desired his uncle to embrace Islam, but Allah did not give hidayah so he remained a polytheist until the end of his life. Allah says:

Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of who are [rightly] guided. (al-Qasas/28: 56)
text.79:
This verse explains that Allah provides food and drink for mankind. Food and drink are sustenance (rizq) from Allah. Allah provides this sustenance by making it easy for humans to obtain it. All of this depends on the skills and knowledge possessed by each individual. Allah sends down rain from the sky as drink for humans, animals, and livestock. With the rainwater, the earth becomes fertile and produces a variety of plants to be enjoyed. Likewise, Allah provides a thousand kinds of valuable objects in the earth's interior, such as iron, oil, gold, aluminum, and so on. All of this is with the intention that they be utilized in the best possible way. Allah says:

"(He is) Who has made the earth a resting place for you and the sky as a canopy, and sent down rain from the sky and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is no equal to Him]." (al-Baqarah/2: 22).
text.80:
This verse explains that it is Allah who heals people when they are sick. Allah has the power to heal any disease that a person suffers from. Even so, humans must also find ways to obtain that healing.

Imam Jamaluddin al-Qasimi, in his tafsir, elaborates that this verse illustrates the ethics of a servant of Allah towards his Creator. This is because illness is sometimes a result of human actions themselves, for example, caused by violations of health norms, or daily lifestyle patterns, so attacks of disease on the body cannot be avoided. Conversely, the one who has the right to heal diseases is Allah alone. If a sick person feels this way when he suffers from illness, then he will truly appreciate the blessings of Allah after he recovers from the disease. Reality does indeed prove that most people are attacked by disease due to a lack of attention to prevailing health norms.
text.81: This verse affirms that Allah is the One who causes people to die, then He is also the One who gives life and resurrects them. No one has the right or ability to do that except Him alone. What is meant by giving life in this verse is resurrecting after death. Between the coming of death and new life is marked by a long period of time, and the timing of its arrival cannot be known by humans. If questioned, death is sometimes also a result of human actions themselves, while in this verse Allah affirms that He alone causes people to die, so how do we distinguish between death attributed to Allah and illness caused by humans? Death is a certain decree that applies to everyone without exception, while illness specifically afflicts a person. This means that not everyone necessarily suffers from a certain type of disease; each of them suffers from different diseases. Often people also die suddenly, without being preceded by illness. It is clear that death is general in nature, while illness specifically afflicts a person.
text.82:
In this verse, it is affirmed that only Allah alone forgives a person's sins on the Day of Judgment (see also Surah ali 'Imran/3: 135). No one can bear the sins of another, but each is responsible for their own actions. Allah says:

And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. (al-An'am/6: 164)
text.83:
Ibrahim prayed to be granted wisdom. Wisdom means knowledge that is practiced well. In relation to the personality of a pious person, wisdom is defined as God's guidance in doing good deeds, with Allah's taufik he is freed from all major and minor sins. Meanwhile, other commentators interpret wisdom as treating fellow humans fairly in deciding a matter. In relation to Ibrahim's prayer, wisdom is interpreted as knowledge of divine attributes and knowledge of the truth that will be practiced in daily life. In addition, he also prayed to be included in the company of good people, and in the group that always trusts in Him. This request was granted by Allah, as mentioned in another verse:

And indeed, in the Hereafter he will be among the righteous. (al-Baqarah/2: 130)

It is narrated in a hadith that the Messenger of Allah prayed like the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim, namely:

"O Allah, let us die in a state of being Muslim, let us live in a state of being Muslim, and include us among the righteous, not among those who are humiliated and afflicted with calamity (fitrah)." (Narrated by Ahmad from Rifa'ah bin Rafi')
text.84:
Furthermore, Ibrahim prayed that his good name would become a good topic of conversation for those who came later, so that he would become the primary role model until the Day of Judgment. This too was granted by Allah, as stated in His word:

And We left for him [favorable mention] among later generations: "Peace upon Ibrahim." Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good. (as-Saffat/37: 108-110).

Allah's promise in the verse above is proven true in the pages of prophetic history. Many of Prophet Ibrahim's descendants became prophets and messengers of Allah, both from the descendants of Ismail and from the descendants of Ishaq. The major religions of the world (Islam, Christianity, and Judaism) each attribute their religion to Prophet Ibrahim. Therefore, he is glorified and respected by various religions in their own ways. Based on this information, it is understandable that they consider Ibrahim to be a Jew (according to the claims of the Jews). Similarly, Ibrahim is regarded as a Christian (according to the beliefs of Christianity), because Isa Almasih, the son of Maryam, is also a descendant of Prophet Ibrahim. In short, in prophetic history, he is considered the father of the prophets. However, all assumptions that Ibrahim was a follower of Judaism or a particular religion are incorrect. The Qur'an refutes such beliefs:

Ibrahim was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists. (ali 'Imran/3: 67)

As for the meaning of a good reputation in this prayer, it is Prophet Muhammad. He is indeed a descendant of Prophet Ibrahim (from the side of Ismail), the last to be appointed as a prophet and messenger. The message of Prophet Muhammad (and also the prophets) is the message of the religion of monotheism (tauhid). The Messenger of Allah himself said in a hadith:

I am (the fulfillment of) the prayer of Ibrahim. (Narrated by Muslim from 'Aisyah)

In essence, the religion conveyed by Prophet Muhammad is a continuation of the teachings conveyed by Prophet Ibrahim.
text.85: After Prophet Ibrahim pleaded for worldly rewards, namely that his good name be made an example for those who came after him, he also prayed to enjoy the recompense of his deeds in the afterlife. That is, the blessings and pleasures of Paradise, along with those who are permitted to enter it. The expression in this verse uses the words "who will inherit Paradise," because it is likened to the pleasure obtained by a king in a kingdom inherited from his father.
text.86:
Then he also prayed for the well-being and safety of his father (Azar) who remained a polytheist. However, after Prophet Ibrahim knew that his father was an enemy of Allah because he associated partners with Him, Ibrahim finally disassociated himself from his father. Allah says:

"And the request of forgiveness of Ibrahim for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became clear to Ibrahim that his father was an enemy to Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed, Ibrahim was one who was soft-hearted and forbearing." (at-Taubah/9: 114).
text.87: Furthermore, Ibrahim supplicated to Allah that he would not experience humiliation on the Day of Judgement. This gives the impression of how humble a prophet is, even though he has attained such a high degree in the sight of Allah, yet he still pleads not to be humiliated on the Day of Judgement. Ibrahim complained to his Lord, saying, "O Lord, have You not promised that I would not be humiliated on the Day of Judgement? What humiliation could be more severe for me than the humiliation of meeting my father in this state?" Allah responded to his prayer by saying, "O Ibrahim, indeed I have forbidden Paradise for the disbelievers."
text.88:
This verse explains the awesomeness of the Day of Judgment. On that day, no one will be safe from Allah's punishment except those who are free from sin and error. The wealth and offspring possessed in the world will not be able to help in the slightest. Allah specifically mentions "children" in this verse because children are the closest and most beneficial to their parents in the world. In another verse, Allah explains that children are the adornment of worldly life. Conversely, righteous deeds and good rewards will endure until the Day of Judgment. When Allah revealed the verse about gold and silver (Surah at-Taubah/9: 34), the companions asked the Messenger of Allah about what wealth they should possess to bring benefit (for the life of the hereafter). The Messenger of Allah replied:

"The best (wealth) is a tongue that always remembers Allah, a heart that is always grateful, and a righteous wife who helps her husband remain faithful." (Narrated by Ahmad and at-Tirmidhi from Thauban)
text.89: This verse explains that the pleasures to be obtained in the afterlife cannot be bought with abundant wealth. Nor can they be exchanged for many children and descendants. Because each person is only saved by their deeds and a pure heart. But those who are saved are only those whose *akidah* is pure from elements of *shirk* and whose character is noble.
text.90:
Paradise is brought so near to the righteous that it can be seen clearly. How Paradise is brought near is explained in another verse:

"And Paradise will be brought near to the righteous, not far away." (Qaf/50:31)

Bringing Paradise near to the righteous will gladden them because the obedience they performed during their time in the world will soon bear fruit. They will soon enter it.
text.91:
Conversely, Hell is also shown to those who are misguided. They witness the horror of its blazing flames. In the Qur'an, it is depicted that the roaring of the Hellfire can be heard even from afar. That will be their abode, without any escape. The verse illustrates how quickly the torment will befall them. Indeed, they never imagined it when they were still in this world, because they did not care about Allah's punishment, as explained in this verse:

And it will be said, "This Day We will forget you as you forgot the meeting of this Day of yours, and your refuge is the Fire, and for you there will be no helpers. (al-Jatsiyah/45: 34)
text.92: Then, when facing the Hellfire that is ready to receive the disbelievers and polytheists, a question is thrown to mock them, "Where are the idol-gods that you used to worship now? Are they able to save you from Allah's torment?" Let alone saving others, those idol-gods are not even able to free themselves.
text.93: Then, when facing the Hellfire that is ready to receive the disbelievers and polytheists, a question is thrown at them to mock them, "Where are the idols that you used to worship now? Are they able to save you from Allah's punishment?" Let alone saving others, those idols are not even capable of freeing themselves.
text.94: Then those who were astray and have been destined as inhabitants of Hell will be overturned together with their leaders and the entire army of Iblis. The army of Iblis in this verse refers to those who like to follow sinful deeds. Both those who follow and the leaders who are followed will be thrown into it (Hell).
text.95: Then the misguided ones, who have been destined as inhabitants of Hell, will be overturned into it, together with their leaders and the entire army of Iblis. The army of Iblis in this verse refers to those who like to follow sinful deeds. Both those who follow and the leaders who are followed will be thrown into it together.
text.96: In hell, the leaders who misled and their followers blame each other. They question each other about who brought them to commit evil deeds that led them to hell.
text.97: After arguing, they both realized that no one was to blame except themselves. They acknowledged that their error was very grave, namely associating partners with Allah (shirk).
text.98: They deeply regret why they considered idols to be equal in power to Allah, such that they worshipped them.
text.99:
Besides their own mistakes, they were also influenced by the evil invitations of their leaders. These leaders were always propagating various actions that violated religion, so they followed them. This is stated again by Allah in another verse:

And they will say, "Our Lord, indeed we obeyed our masters and our great ones, and they led us astray from the [right] way." (al-Ahzab/33: 67)

The structure of this verse very clearly explains the regret of those who follow a leader without realizing where they are being led. So, we are not obligated to obey a leader if we are certain that the leader is actually leading to disobedience.
text.100: The disbelievers and polytheists only realize in the Hereafter that there is no one else, not even angels, who will help them escape from Allah's punishment that is already before their eyes. If only, in the world they had believed and done righteous deeds, surely that would have given them intercession (shafa'at).
text.101:
Close friends or even family members, they realize, will be unable to help. In another verse it is mentioned:

"Then are there for us any intercessors to intercede for us so we may be returned [to the world] and do other than what we were doing?" (al-A'raf/7: 53).
text.102: They hope to be returned to the world. If that wish were granted, they promise they would believe and do righteous deeds. However, that is not possible. That is only their excuse, because even if they were returned to the world, they would still disbelieve again.
text.103: Thus are some of the explanations of God that Ibrahim conveyed to his people. With the aforementioned proofs, it is clear that the core of the teachings he conveyed to his people was the understanding of *tauhid* (monotheism) and belief in the Day of Resurrection. There is no being worthy of worship except Allah, the One and Only. Only most people do not want to understand or do not want to accept that truth.
text.104: Allah, in His might and with His attribute of the Most Merciful, constantly reminds those who are misguided and unwilling to believe in His verses. Allah sends messengers to them so that they may obtain guidance from Him. Allah sends those messengers with teachings and religious laws, so that they and their descendants may follow them.
text.105:
These verses explain that Prophet Noah was rejected by his people when he conveyed the religion of Allah to them. Even though they only rejected Prophet Noah himself, this action meant rejecting the other messengers of Allah, both those sent before and after Prophet Noah. This is because the message brought by the messengers is fundamentally the same, namely the creed of *tauhid* (monotheism).

Prophet Noah was the third prophet sent by Allah, after Prophet Adam and Prophet Idris. Prophet Noah was also the first messenger, based on the *hadith qudsi*:

From Abu Hurairah r.a. that the Prophet saw said, "Allah said, 'O Noah, you are the first messenger sent to earth.'" (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

The meaning of the first messenger here is the first messenger of Allah sent after Prophet Adam and Prophet Idris. He is also called the second father of mankind after Adam, because some *mufassir* (interpreters of the Quran) believe that all humans were destroyed and died because of the storm and flood, except for those who were on the ark with Prophet Noah. Among those who survived were his three sons, namely Sam, Ham, and Japheth. So all humans that exist until now are descended from the descendants of Prophet Noah's three sons.

There is no definite information about the time gap between Adam and Idris with Prophet Noah. There are only some different accounts in the Hebrew Torah, the Samaritan Torah, and the translation of the Torah in Greek.

Prophet Noah was sent to his brothers, meaning people who were still considered relatives of Noah. In other surahs, it is mentioned that Noah was sent to his people.

The people of Prophet Noah worshipped statues and idols that they considered to be gods. Therefore, Prophet Noah reminded them to be pious to Allah and fear His severe punishment. That punishment would be inflicted by Allah upon those who deny the call of His prophet.

The people of Prophet Noah worshipped statues and idols that they considered to be gods. Therefore, Prophet Noah reminded them to be pious to Allah and fear His severe punishment. That punishment would be inflicted by Allah upon those who denied the call of His prophet.
text.107:
Prophet Noah informed his people that he was a messenger of Allah sent to them. He was entrusted to convey Allah's commands and prohibitions, without adding or subtracting even a little.

In Surah Hud/11:31, it is explained that Prophet Noah did not possess wealth to give to his people. Therefore, he could not promise them property and riches. He also did not know the unseen (ghaib), never said that he was an angel, and did not promise pleasure and happiness to those who followed his call. All of that is only known, possessed, and determined by Allah, because He is the Almighty. Noah was only tasked with conveying it.
text.108:
This verse explains the content of the message conveyed by Prophet Noah to his people, which was to fear Allah and worship Him alone. In verse 3 of Surah Nuh, three things are mentioned that Allah commanded: to worship only Allah, to fear Him, and to obey Prophet Noah.

In other verses, it is explained that the message brought by Prophet Noah also mentioned the following:

1.  The good consequences that those who fear Allah will obtain. Allah will increase their sustenance and send down rain. Then, with that water, Allah will fertilize the earth and grow plants.

2.  Presenting evidence of Allah's oneness and power, and explaining evidence of the truth of the message he brought. Among them is about the creation of humans in several stages of creation, starting from a drop of sperm until being born as a human. Allah created the heavens and the earth, the shining moon and the radiant sun, gives life and causes death to humans, and then all humans will return to Him.
text.109: In this verse, it is explained that in carrying out the task of conveying the religion of Allah, Prophet Noah would not ask for wages from anyone, and would not expect wealth, power, or grandeur in the slightest. He only sought the pleasure and reward from Allah.
text.110:
In this verse, Prophet Noah repeats and reaffirms Allah's command for his people to be pious and obedient to Him. This repetition is to emphasize to his people that piety towards Allah is very important and obligatory for every human being, as a sign of gratitude for the countless blessings that He has bestowed upon them. Piety is the source of all goodness and is the key to opening the gates of pleasure and happiness in the Hereafter.

Prophet Noah strove with all his might to convey his message by presenting Allah's promises and threats to those who did not follow the call of the messenger. He also presented evidence of the truth of the message he brought to them. Nevertheless, his people still did not accept him.
text.111:
This verse explains the attitude of Noah's people towards his call. They said that there was no reason for them to follow Noah's call because none of the intelligent and wise people among them were interested in it, let alone their leaders. Only the foolish and weak, or those who wanted something, were willing to become followers of the Prophet Noah. Allah says:

So the eminent among those who disbelieved from his people said, "We do not see you but as a man like ourselves, and we do not see anyone following you except those who are the lowest of us [and] hastily [accepting]. And we do not see in you any merit above us; rather, we think you are liars." (Hud/11: 27)
text.112: In this verse, Prophet Noah answered his people's objections by saying that he did not know the true state of those who followed his call. He was not commissioned by Allah to investigate their origins or their respective positions in society. He was only commissioned to convey the religion of Allah to his people. If any of them believed, then he only viewed them according to their outward appearance, not according to their position in society, their competence and intelligence, and neither according to their wealth and poverty.
text.113: Prophet Noah entrusted the reckoning of all the deeds performed by his believing followers entirely to Allah, because He is the Knower of all things. He is the One authorized to judge the deeds of His servants, and He is the One who gives the recompense. Good deeds are rewarded with manifold rewards, while bad deeds are recompensed with a proportionate punishment. That is the law of Allah. They should have known that law of Allah.
text.114:
Even though Prophet Noah had strived day and night to call his people, they still did not heed him. According to his people, believing in Noah meant degrading themselves by joining the lowly. They even forced Noah to immediately expel the believers from their land, so as not to demean the dignity and religion of their ancestors.

Prophet Noah answered his people's request by saying that he would not expel the believers, even if they were poor, or came from a low class according to his people's view. According to Allah's view, they were all people who were pious. A person's faith and obedience are what determine whether he is a good and noble person or a despicable one.
text.115: Furthermore, Noah told his people that he was only a messenger sent by Allah to them to convey His religion. He also delivered warnings and threats that Allah's punishment would be inflicted upon those who disbelieved and were disobedient, as well as those who denied the call of the messenger. As for those who followed the call of the messenger, and heeded the words and threats, whether rich or poor, noble or common, Allah would reward them with a Paradise full of delights.
text.116:
Thus did Prophet Noah fulfill his duty as a messenger of Allah. He strove with all his might to deliver the call of Allah, day and night, both secretly and openly. The more diligently Prophet Noah called them, the stronger the obstacles and hindrances his people gave him. Their attitude is depicted in the word of Allah:

"And indeed, every time I invited them that You might forgive them, they put their fingers in their ears, covered themselves with their garments, persisted, and were greatly arrogant." (Nuh/71:7).

Finally, they threatened Prophet Noah to immediately stop his efforts to invite them to follow the religion he was preaching. If he continued his efforts and did not stop, they would stone and destroy Prophet Noah.
text.117: Receiving such a threat, Prophet Noah could do nothing more than complain to Allah that his people had denied him. He hoped that with this prayer he would receive help from Allah.
text.118: Furthermore, Prophet Noah prayed that Allah would give a just decision regarding the problems that occurred between him and his people. He had exerted all his energy and ability to bring them to the right path, but their response was instead threats to harm him. Prophet Noah was certain that these threats were not empty. Therefore, Prophet Noah truly prayed that he and the believing followers would be saved by Allah from these threats.
text.119:
Allah answered the prayer of Prophet Noah and commanded him, along with the believers, to build a large ship that could carry them all, along with their necessities and equipment.

Prophet Noah and his followers began building the ship. His people were astonished and amazed at what he was doing. They did not know what Prophet Noah was building. His people considered Prophet Noah and the believers, especially those who helped him build the ship, to be crazy. Everyone who passed near Prophet Noah building the ship mocked and ridiculed his actions.

Allah's command for Prophet Noah to build the ship and the attitude of Prophet Noah's people are explained in His word:

"And construct the ship under Our observation and revelation, and do not address Me concerning those who have wronged; indeed, they are to be drowned." And he began to construct the ship, and whenever the eminent of his people passed him, they ridiculed him. He said, "If you ridicule us, then we will ridicule you just as you ridicule [us]. And you are going to know who will get a punishment that will disgrace [him] and upon whom will descend an enduring punishment." (Hud/11: 37-39).

Prophet Noah answered the mockery by reminding them of Allah's punishment that would be inflicted upon the disbelievers who did not heed the call of His messenger. If they continued to behave in this way, then the punishment would come soon. At the time of receiving the punishment and disaster, they would regret it forever. However, that regret would be of no use because all doors of repentance had been closed to them. Allah reminded Prophet Noah not to serve those who were unjust anymore, because their faith could no longer be hoped for, and it had become Allah's decree to destroy them.

Prophet Noah and the believers with him had earnestly strived to carry out Allah's command to build the ship. After it was finished, the moments promised by Allah arrived, namely destroying the disbelievers and saving the believers. At that time, the earth gushed forth water from all directions and overflowed, like the overflow of water boiling in a cooking pot. In a short time, the water had submerged the surface of the earth.

At that time, Allah commanded Prophet Noah to order the believers to board the ship, bringing the necessary equipment. Allah also commanded them to bring their livestock, each a male and a female, so that they could reproduce later after the storm and flood stopped.

According to some *mufasir*, only one believing wife and three sons, namely Sam, Ham, and Japheth, of Prophet Noah's family entered the ship. Thus, Prophet Noah began to sail by mentioning the name of Allah, navigating the flood like the sea, facing waves that towered like mountains.
text.120:
In the Quran, it is depicted how immense the waves were and how Prophet Noah tried to save his disbelieving son. He called him to board the ark together with the believers. However, his invitation was ignored, and Prophet Noah's son drowned with the other disbelievers. This story is mentioned in Allah's word:

"And it sailed with them through waves like mountains, and Noah called to his son who was apart [from them], "O my son, come aboard with us and be not with the disbelievers." He said, "I will take refuge on a mountain to protect me from the water." [Noah] said, "There is no protector today from the decree of Allah, except for whom He gives mercy." And the wave came between them, and he was among the drowned." (Hud/11: 42-43).

Prophet Noah's ark sailed in a direction unknown to its passengers. Only Allah knew its destination.

At the time appointed by Allah, the storm ceased and the flood receded, as if the water was swallowed by the earth. Prophet Noah's ark landed on the peak of a hill called Judi. Most commentators believe that Mount Judi is located in Southern Armenia, bordering Mesopotamia, famous for Mount Arafat.

With the end of the storm and the great flood, and the safe landing of Prophet Noah's ark on Mount Judi, Allah had fulfilled His promise. He saved the believers who followed Prophet Noah's call and destroyed the disbelievers who denied his call.

After the ark landed, Prophet Noah remembered his drowned son. He pleaded for his son's safety because he was part of his family. However, Allah reminded Prophet Noah that his son was no longer his family because he had become a disbeliever. Allah said:

"And Noah called upon his Lord and said, "My Lord, indeed my son is of my family, and indeed Your promise is ever true; and You are the most just of judges!" He said, "O Noah, indeed he is not of your family; indeed, he is [one whose] work was other than righteous, so ask Me not for that about which you have no knowledge. Indeed, I advise you, lest you be among the ignorant." (Hud/11: 45-46).

The believers with Prophet Noah who survived the storm and flood then multiplied, up to the humans of today. Among them are believers and disbelievers. Some are afflicted with punishment in this world and destroyed, and some are saved. Some are happy and some are miserable, some are rich and some are poor. Allah said:

"[It was] said, "O Noah, disembark in peace from Us and with blessings upon you and upon nations [descending] from those with you. But there will be nations to whom We will grant enjoyment; then there will touch them from Us a painful punishment." (Hud/11: 48).
text.121: After explaining the story of Prophet Noah and his people, the destruction experienced by those who denied the messenger's call, and the victory obtained by those who believed, Allah then directs this His word to Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims. Allah reminds that the above event should be a lesson or moral. Mankind should believe in Prophet Muhammad and accept his call. If they deny him, then the same thing can happen to them. Allah is able to carry out His threat if He wills. However, Allah still gives mankind an opportunity, because He is the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful.
text.122: After explaining the story of Prophet Noah and his people, the destruction experienced by those who denied the messenger's call, and the victory obtained by those who believed, Allah then directs this word to Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims. Allah reminds that the above event should be a lesson or *i'tibar*. Humanity should believe in Prophet Muhammad and accept his call. If they deny him, the same thing can happen to them. Allah is able to carry out His threat if He wills. However, Allah still gives humanity a chance, because He is the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful.
text.123:
This verse explains that Allah sent Prophet Hud, peace be upon him, to the people of 'Ad, but they denied and rejected his call. 'Ad is the name of a people, taken from the name of their ancestor named 'Ad. 'Ad was one of the descendants of Sam bin Noah. Prophet Hud himself was one of the descendants of 'Ad, namely Hud bin Abdullah bin Rabah bin Khulud bin 'Ad. That is why in this verse, Prophet Hud is called a brother of the people of 'Ad, which means that Prophet Hud was one of the citizens of the people of 'Ad.

The people of 'Ad resided in al-Ahqaf, which is now known as the Sahara al-Ahqaf. This area is now part of the southern part of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Al-Ahqaf is located north of Hadramaut, northeast of Yemen, south of Nejed, and west of Oman. Now that place is also called ar-Rab' al-Khali, meaning "the empty place" because the place is indeed empty, uninhabited. On maps, it is usually written Rub' al-Khali, which is incorrect, the correct one is Rab' not Rub'.

The people of 'Ad were initially monotheistic, the religion adhered to by their ancestors and in accordance with human nature. However, after their kingdom expanded and grew due to the conquest of other nations around them, they became arrogant and worshiped idols. The idols that were worshiped were idols of their leaders, which were initially made only to honor and commemorate their services. However, over time, they worshiped these idols. There were three idols they worshiped, namely Saba', Samud, and Haba. To return them to the true religion, Allah sent a messenger to them, namely Prophet Hud, who was also one of their citizens.
text.124:
This verse explains that Allah sent Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) to the 'Ad people, but they denied and rejected his call. 'Ad is the name of a people, taken from the name of their ancestor named 'Ad. 'Ad was one of the descendants of Sam bin Noah. Prophet Hud himself was one of the descendants of 'Ad, namely Hud bin Abdullah bin Rabah bin Khulud bin 'Ad. That is why in this verse, Prophet Hud is called a brother of the 'Ad people, meaning that Prophet Hud was one of the members of the 'Ad people.

The 'Ad people resided in al-Ahqaf, which is now known as the Sahara al-Ahqaf. This area is now part of the southern part of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Al-Ahqaf is located north of Hadramaut, northeast of Yemen, south of Nejed, and west of Oman. Now that place is also called ar-Rab' al-Khali, meaning "the empty place" because the place is indeed empty, uninhabited. On maps, it is usually written Rub' al-Khali, which is incorrect; the correct term is Rab', not Rub'.

The 'Ad people were initially monotheistic, adhering to the religion of their ancestors, which was also in accordance with human nature (fitrah). However, after their kingdom expanded and grew due to the conquest of other nations around them, they became arrogant and worshipped idols. The idols they worshipped were idols of their leaders, which were initially made only to honor and commemorate their services. However, over time, they worshipped these idols. There were three idols they worshipped: Saba', Samud, and Haba. To return them to the true religion, Allah sent a messenger to them, namely Prophet Hud, who was also one of their own people.
text.125:
Prophet Hud, peace be upon him, called upon them to worship Allah and be mindful of Him, to carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions. In Surah Hud/11: 50-54, it is explained that Prophet Hud asked his people to worship Allah and not to worship idols, because there is no god but Allah. This means that there is none who creates, provides sustenance, gives life and death, has power, resurrects from the grave, and possesses the attributes of divinity, except Allah. The worship of idols was an act they fabricated themselves, not based on any explanation from the holy book or any real evidence. Hud also stated that he was a true messenger of Allah. Everything he conveyed came from Allah.

Prophet Hud explained that he did not expect any reward for his work in calling people to the religion of monotheism. His reward was solely from Allah, namely the reward he hoped for in the Hereafter.

Prophet Hud called upon his people to seek forgiveness and repent to Allah. If they did so, Allah would surely forgive their sins, send down rain that would make their land more fertile, and increase their sustenance. In addition, Allah would make them stronger, both physically and in power. Prophet Hud reminded them to stop the sinful deeds they were doing and to seek Allah's forgiveness.

And (Hud said), "O my people, ask forgiveness of your Lord and then repent to Him. He will send [rain from] the sky upon you in showers and increase you in strength [added] to your strength. And do not turn away, [being] criminals." (Hud/11: 52).

The people of 'Ad did not heed the call of Prophet Hud; in fact, they stated that Prophet Hud did not bring any truth in his da'wah (call/invitation). They affirmed that they would not abandon the worship of idols and did not believe in the call of Prophet Hud. Allah says:

They (the people of 'Ad) said, "O Hud, you have not brought us clear evidence, and we are not ones to leave our gods for your saying, nor are we believers in you. (Hud/11: 53).

They accused Prophet Hud of being afflicted with madness inflicted by their idols. Allah says:

We only say that some of our gods have possessed you with evil." (Hud/11: 54).
text.126:
Prophet Hud, peace be upon him, called upon them to worship Allah and be mindful of Him, to carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions. In Surah Hud/11: 50-54, it is explained that Prophet Hud asked his people to worship Allah and not to worship idols, because there is no god but Allah. This means that there is none who creates, provides sustenance, gives life and death, has power, raises from the grave, and possesses divine attributes, except Allah. The worship of idols was an act they invented themselves, not based on any explanation from holy scriptures or any real evidence. Hud also stated that he was a true messenger of Allah. Everything he conveyed came from Allah.

Prophet Hud explained that he did not expect any reward for his work in calling people to the religion of monotheism. His reward was solely from Allah, namely the reward he hoped for in the Hereafter.

If they did so, Allah would surely forgive their sins, send down rain that would make their land more fertile, and increase their sustenance.
