And (Hud said), "O my people, ask forgiveness of your Lord and then repent to Him. He will send [rain from] the sky upon you in showers and increase you in strength [added] to your strength. And do not turn away, [being] criminals." (Hud/11: 52).

The people of 'Ad did not heed the call of Prophet Hud; instead, they stated that Prophet Hud did not bring any truth in his da'wah (call/invitation). They affirmed that they would not abandon the worship of idols and did not believe in the call of Prophet Hud. Allah says:

They (the people of 'Ad) said, "O Hud, you have not brought us clear evidence, and we are not ones to leave our gods for your saying, nor will we believe you. (Hud/11: 53).

They accused Prophet Hud of being afflicted with madness inflicted by their idols. Allah says:

We only say that some of our gods have possessed you with evil." (Hud/11: 54).
text.127:
Prophet Hud, peace be upon him, called them to worship Allah and be mindful of Him, to carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions. In Surah Hud/11: 50-54, it is explained that Prophet Hud asked his people to worship Allah and not to worship idols, because there is no god but Allah. This means that there is no one who creates, provides sustenance, gives life and death, has power, raises from the grave, and possesses divine attributes, except Allah. The worship of idols was an act they invented themselves, not based on information from holy books or any real evidence. Hud also stated that he was a true messenger of Allah. Everything he conveyed came from Allah.

Prophet Hud explained that he did not expect any reward for his work in calling people to the religion of monotheism. His reward was solely from Allah, namely the reward he hoped for in the Hereafter.

Prophet Hud called his people to seek forgiveness and repent to Allah. If they did so, Allah would surely forgive their sins, send down rain that would make their land more fertile, and increase their sustenance. In addition, Allah would make them stronger, both physically and in power. Prophet Hud reminded them to stop the sins they were committing and to seek Allah's forgiveness.

And (Hud said), "O my people, ask forgiveness of your Lord and then repent to Him. He will send [rain from] the sky upon you in showers and increase you in strength [added] to your strength. And do not turn away, [being] criminals." (Hud/11: 52).

The people of 'Ad did not heed the call of Prophet Hud; in fact, they stated that Prophet Hud did not bring any truth in his da'wah (call/invitation). They affirmed that they would not abandon the worship of idols and did not believe in the call of Prophet Hud. Allah says:

They (the people of 'Ad) said, "O Hud, you have not brought us clear evidence, and we are not ones to leave our gods for your saying, nor are we believers in you. (Hud/11: 53).

They accused Prophet Hud of being afflicted with madness inflicted by their idols. Allah says:

We only say that some of our gods have possessed you with evil." (Hud/11: 54).
text.128:
Hud questioned his people's habit of erecting buildings on hilltops or on every road solely to display greatness, magnificence, and wealth. Why didn't they build them based on usefulness and other positive goals?

The people of 'Ad indeed possessed a high civilization according to the standards of their time. They were able to establish a strong state, well-organized regions and cities, along with magnificent buildings. This construction was not for good purposes, but solely to show off their wealth.

No historian has been able to ascertain the period of the 'Ad kingdom's glory. Some estimate that the 'Ad kingdom was contemporary with the Babylonian kingdom, approximately 2000 years before Christ. However, this does not correspond to reality because Prophet Hud was sent to the people of 'Ad before Prophet Ibrahim was sent to Babylon, namely during the time of Nebuchadnezzar.
text.129:
This verse explains Hud's warning to his people who built palaces and strong fortresses with the intention of living forever in the world, even though only Allah is the Almighty.

History proves that 'Ad was able to build companies, mine metals in the earth, and make canals for regular irrigation. With regular irrigation, their land became fertile, so their prosperity increased. They founded the city of Iram with tall and magnificent pillars as the capital of their kingdom. Its founder was named Shaddad bin 'Ad, one of their kings. Around this city, they built strong fortresses to defend it from enemy attacks.

The prosperity and strength they possessed made them arrogant and haughty. They thought that their condition would last forever. They rebelled against Allah by worshiping idols and acting arbitrarily. Allah says:

"As for 'Ad, they were arrogant in the land without right and said, "Who is greater than us in strength?" Did they not consider that Allah who created them was greater than them in strength? And they were rejecting Our signs." (Fussilat/41: 15).
text.130: This verse explains the coarse and cruel behavior of the 'Ad people. When they tortured their enemies, they did so cruelly without any compassion. They were gifted with strong, tall, and mighty bodies. Their character was also in accordance with their mighty bodies. With the strength they possessed, they attacked other lands, reaching as far as the lands of Syria and Iraq. In warfare, they acted and treated their enemies cruelly.
text.131: Seeing such an attitude, Prophet Hud reminded them to be pious and devote themselves to Allah. Prophet Hud reminded them of the blessings that Allah had bestowed upon them. Therefore, they should be grateful for these blessings so that Allah would increase them with even more and higher-valued blessings.
text.132: Seeing such an attitude, Prophet Hud reminded them to be pious and to devote themselves to Allah. Prophet Hud reminded them of the blessings that Allah had bestowed upon them. Therefore, they should be grateful for these blessings so that Allah would increase them with even more and more valuable blessings.
text.133: Among the blessings that Allah bestowed upon the people of 'Ad were livestock that they could utilize, and offspring who could continue their generations and carry on their aspirations. They were also granted beautiful gardens, grown with plants that were very useful to them. Likewise, water that could irrigate the land as a result of irrigation that they had created, all with the help of Allah.
text.134: Among the blessings that Allah bestowed upon the people of 'Ad were livestock that they could utilize, and offspring who could continue their generations and carry on their aspirations. They were also granted beautiful gardens, grown with plants that were very useful to them. Likewise, water that could irrigate the land as a result of irrigation that they had created, all with the help of Allah.
text.135: Prophet Hud conveyed to them that all that they had acquired was a blessing from Allah. He feared that the countless blessings they had obtained would be withdrawn or stopped, as a punishment from Allah for their denial and arrogance. Were they not afraid that such a thing would happen? According to the sunnah of Allah, He will increase blessings for those who are grateful for His blessings and will punish those who deny them.
text.136: This verse explains that the people of 'Ad still did not heed the call of Prophet Hud, even saying, "In our opinion, it is all the same whether you give a warning or not, we remain firm in our stance. We no longer want to hear your words, and we will not retreat even a little from our position."
text.137:
Furthermore, they said that the religion they adhered to was the religion of their ancestors, which had been passed down to them. They were convinced that they would not be punished for following the religion of their ancestors.

In another verse, it is explained that Hud challenged his increasingly disbelieving people by calling on them to make an effort to kill him, done collectively. Hud also ordered them to include the gods they worshipped, if they truly believed in the ability of those gods to do what they wanted. It was as if Hud said to them, "Unite yourselves with the gods you worship to kill me, and carry out the killing right now, do not postpone it any longer. I am not afraid at all of being killed because I put my trust in Allah, my Lord and your true Lord. Every creature on earth is always guarded, maintained, and controlled by Allah, and His words are always true and straight."

The challenge that Hud put forward to his people is proof that he was a messenger sent by Allah. If he were not a messenger, he would not have dared to make such a challenge to his people, who were stronger in body and more cruel in nature.
text.138:

text.139:
This verse explains that the 'Ad people remained disobedient and did not heed the call of Prophet Hud. In another of His verses, Prophet Hud threatened his people, saying that if they persisted in disbelief, they would be destroyed by Allah and replaced with another people, who would rule and become the progenitors of future generations. While they would not be able to cause Allah any harm. Allah says:

"So if you turn away, then I have already conveyed to you that with which I was sent to you. And my Lord will replace you with another people, while you will not harm Him at all. Indeed, my Lord is Guardian over all things." (Hud/11: 57).

Among the 'Ad people, some believed in Prophet Hud, but the majority of them remained disbelievers. The 'Ad people who did not believe were destroyed by Allah by sending a bitterly cold wind, until they died prostrate, their cities and lands collapsed and were buried in the ground, as Allah says:

"And as for 'Ad, they were destroyed by a furious, bitterly cold wind. He subjected it to them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so you would see the people therein fallen as if they were hollow trunks of palm trees. Then do you see of them any remnant?" (Al-Haqqah/69: 6-8).

The 'Ad people who disbelieved and were destroyed by Allah are called 'Ä€d al-Â¸la ('the first 'Ad'). As for those who believed and were saved by Allah together with Prophet Hud, they are called 'ad ats-saniyah ('the second 'Ad').

Among those who believed, some migrated with Prophet Hud to the south, namely Hadramaut. Until now, in that area, there is still a city called Madinah Qabri Hud, located east of the city of Tariem, one of the largest cities in Hadramaut. In Madinah Qabri Hud, there is a tomb called Qabri Hud, which has been preserved until now, to serve as evidence of the truth of the story of Hud mentioned in the Al-Qur'an.

Even though the land of the 'Ad people is buried in the ground due to Allah's punishment, there are still signs that the place was once inhabited by people with a high civilization. In the Al-Qur'an, there are many verses that instruct people to travel the earth to observe the remains of settlements of people who have been destroyed by Allah, including the people of Hud, to be taken as a lesson.

In the 20th century, expeditions led by Western scholars came there, including one led by H. St. John Philby, who was able to conduct an expedition to ar-Rub' al-Khali with the permission of the King of Saudi Arabia, Abdul Aziz Alu Su'ud. He wrote a book entitled The Heart of Arabia. A Dutch scholar, Van der Mulen, also led an expedition to the area around ar-Rab' al-Khali and wrote a book entitled Hadramaut.

The story of Prophet Hud and his people is only mentioned in the Al-Qur'an, not found in other Abrahamic scriptures (kitab-kitab Samawi). In the story of the people of Hud, there is a lesson for Muslims, because those who were destroyed were those who did not believe.
text.140: Allah explains in this verse that the Lord of Muhammad is the Almighty Lord in taking retribution from those who are disobedient, and His mercy is bestowed upon His believing servants.
text.141:
This verse explains that the people of Thamud had denied the messenger sent to them, namely the Prophet Salih (al-A'raf/7: 73-79). Prophet Salih was a descendant of a person named Thamud. In other words, Prophet Salih and the people of Thamud both originated from the lineage of Thamud. According to one narration, Thamud was the son of 'Ad, while according to another narration, Thamud was a cousin of 'Ad. Despite these differences, it can be established that the people of Thamud and the people of 'Ad had a close relationship. Thamud was the son of Aus bin Aram bin Sam bin Nuh.

The people of Thamud resided in the city of Hijr (Mada'in Salih) up to Wadi al-Qura, a place located between Hejaz and Syria, southeast of the land of Madyan. Their relics still exist in this area today, which generally show their former power and the prosperity they had achieved. Their period of life was after the period of the people of 'Ad, and the sending of Prophet Salih to the people of Thamud was before the sending of Prophet Ibrahim to the Babylonian nation (see the vocabulary of Thamud in this Tafsir).
text.142:
Prophet Salih called the people of Thamud to return to the religion of monotheism and to fear Allah. Initially, they believed in Allah, then became disbelievers and worshipped idols that they associated with Him. To bring them back to the religion of monotheism, Allah sent Prophet Salih to them. Prophet Salih called his people to fear Allah, to carry out His commands and abandon His prohibitions, and to acknowledge that Prophet Salih was a messenger sent by Allah to them.

In Surah Hud, it is explained that Prophet Salih called his people to believe in the religion of monotheism. The core of his da'wah (call) was to worship Allah, meaning that only Allah should be worshipped, not the statues they made. To strengthen his da'wah, Prophet Salih conveyed the reason that there is no god but Allah who created them, provides for them, gives life and death, and made them merchants, shepherds, entrepreneurs, and cultivators of the earth, as Allah says:

"And to Thamud (We sent) their brother Salih. He said, "O my people! Worship Allah, you have no god other than Him. He brought you forth from the earth and settled you therein. So ask forgiveness of Him and then repent to Him. Indeed, my Lord is Near and Responsive." (Hud/11: 61).

Prophet Salih explained his reason, which is that Allah created them from the earth, that is, from soil. This was a real thing for them, they could not deny it. Prophet Salih also said that Allah had made them cultivators of the earth. This was also a reality for them. They had indeed cultivated the earth by utilizing water sources, building irrigation systems that functioned to regulate water distribution, until their land became fertile, their plants grew and bore fruit, and their livestock lived well. They had also extracted metals from the earth that were beneficial for companies and commerce. Thus, they had cultivated and prospered the earth, and this was a real thing they experienced every day.

Prophet Salih explained that he would not ask for any reward from them. He only expected a reward from Allah who sent him.

text.146:
Prophet Saleh reminded them of the blessings of Allah that had been bestowed upon them, namely:

1. They lived safely in their land, free from enemy disturbances, and obtained happiness and peace of mind.

2. They had fertile agricultural land, many livestock, and sources of water that could be used to create organized irrigation canals. They lived as farmers, shepherds, merchants, and miners of metals from the earth. Therefore, their land became beautiful, filled with plants that pleased the eyes of those who looked at them. Some of them even said that their land was actually the paradise promised by Allah.

3. They were given the ability to carve mountains of rock to be used as dwellings.

These were the various blessings of Allah that had been bestowed upon the people of Thamud. They should have been grateful for the blessings that Allah had given them, but day by day they became more arrogant. They felt that their happiness and pleasure were only due to their own efforts, not because of Allah's blessings. Therefore, they did not believe in the Day of Judgment. According to them, the real life was life in this world, and they wanted to live forever in this world.

The people of Thamud no longer thought about what their fate would be if, at some point, Allah suddenly took away all their happiness and prosperity and replaced it with a terrible disaster. All of that could be done by Allah because of their own denial and arrogance.

This verse contains the meaning of how, with strong intellect, humans can carve mountain rocks to be used as dwellings, as was done by the people of Thamud. At this time, the technology of carving tools has developed and is used by humans to meet their needs, including cutting and splitting hard mountain rocks. These tools are fully powered by machines or robots. Humans have even been able to create super-sophisticated carving technology where objects are cut or split with laser beams. The results are very smooth and precise. With this sophisticated tool, even very hard granite rocks become easy to split or cut. That is the result of human thought.

Prophet Saleh also invited them to perform deeds that are pleasing to Allah and beneficial for their lives in this world and the hereafter, namely to worship Allah who has bestowed various blessings upon them. Prophet Saleh reminded them not to obey their leaders who always commit evil, disobedience, and corruption on this earth.

text.153: All that Prophet Saleh presented to his people, in the form of proofs of the truth of his da'wah (call to Islam), they could not refute. In fact, their hearts acknowledged the truth that was conveyed to them, but their corrupted souls caused them to deny Prophet Saleh's call. Therefore, they said to Prophet Saleh, "O Saleh, you are presenting something to us that aims for us to abandon the religion of our ancestors, and follow the religion that you bring. The ways in which you convey this religion are very attractive and mesmerizing to us, as if you have bewitched us. Actually, you are crazy and have been affected by magic, because our god has afflicted you with madness, so it is no longer fitting for us to listen to your words and accept your invitation."
text.154:
The people of Thamud still did not believe in the prophethood of Prophet Saleh because, according to them, he was just an ordinary human being like them. A messenger sent by Allah should not be an ordinary human being, but an angel or a creature different from them. A messenger must be able to do something miraculous and strange, which humans are unable to do. Therefore, they asked Prophet Saleh to bring a miracle as proof of his prophethood, or to show that he was truly a prophet sent by Allah to them.

Allah fulfilled their wish by bringing a female camel as a miracle for Prophet Saleh. They were forbidden to disturb the camel, and to let it eat and drink as it pleased. Prophet Saleh threatened them, saying that they would soon be punished by Allah if they disturbed the camel.

The aspects of the camel's miraculous nature, according to the commentators (mufasir), are:

1. The camel came out of a rock, while other camels did not.

2. The drinking water sources of the inhabitants were divided into two between the camel and the inhabitants of the land. On the day the camel drank, the inhabitants were not allowed to take water. To meet their drinking water needs, they were allowed to milk the camel. When it was the inhabitants' turn to take water, the camel did not come to drink water at that place.

3. On the day the camel drank, other animals did not come to that place.

The extraordinary nature of the camel was clear evidence of Saleh's prophethood. They would be destroyed by Allah if they violated His command regarding the camel.

Therefore, they wanted to kill it and challenge what had been threatened to them. Prophet Saleh said that they would be destroyed by Allah after three days had passed because of the act of killing the camel.
text.155:
The people of Thamud still did not believe in the prophethood of Prophet Saleh because, according to them, he was just an ordinary human being like them. A messenger sent by Allah should not be an ordinary human being, but an angel or a creature different from them. A messenger should be able to do something miraculous and strange, which humans are unable to do. Therefore, they asked Prophet Saleh to bring a miracle as proof of his prophethood, or something that would show that he was truly a prophet sent by Allah to them.

Allah fulfilled their wish by bringing a female camel as a miracle for Prophet Saleh. They were forbidden to disturb the camel, and to let it eat and drink as it pleased. Prophet Saleh threatened them, saying that they would soon be punished by Allah if they disturbed the camel.

According to the commentators (mufasir), the aspects of the camel's miraculous nature were:

1. The camel came out of a rock, while other camels did not.

2. The drinking water sources of the inhabitants were divided into two between the camel and the inhabitants of the land. On the day the camel drank, the inhabitants were not allowed to take water. To meet their drinking water needs, they were allowed to milk the camel. When it was the inhabitants' turn to take water, the camel did not come to drink water at that place.

3. On the day the camel drank, other animals did not come to that place.

text.157:
(157-159) These verses explain that the people of Thamud wanted to prove the truth of Prophet Salih's words, so they killed the camel. However, after they slaughtered the camel, especially after seeing the signs of Allah's punishment about to arrive, they regretted it. Even more so when their land was shaken by an earthquake accompanied by lightning and thunderbolts that flattened their houses.

In the Qur'an, there are verses that explain the various punishments that destroyed them. Some verses explain that they were destroyed by *sa‘iqah* (lightning) (Fussilat/41:17 and ad-dariyat/51:44). Meanwhile, other verses mention *rajfah* (a very violent earthquake) (al-A‘raf/7:78). In other verses, it is called *saihah* (a very loud sound from the sky) (Hud/11:67; al-Hijr/15:83; and al-Qamar/54:31). There are also those who mention that they were destroyed by *Tagiyah* (an extraordinary event) (al-Haqqah/69:5).

These verses are not contradictory because they were destroyed by lightning (*Sa‘iqah*). As for the very violent earthquake (*rajfah*), the loud sound from the sky (*saihah*), and the extraordinary event (*tagiyah*), these are symptoms and characteristics of the lightning. The lightning was so powerful that it shook the earth and produced a very loud sound. All of this destroyed them, and this was an extraordinary event. In the blink of an eye, they had become motionless bodies, dead and fallen in their homes. Then they disappeared from the face of the earth, nothing was visible except their dwellings, as if they had never lived and been in that place. Because they had been destroyed by Allah, in history they are included as one of the extinct Arab nations (*al-‘Arab al-Ba‘idah*).

Prophet Salih and the believers were saved by Allah from that punishment. They took refuge in Ramallah, one of the cities in Palestine. In this city, there is the tomb of Prophet Salih which is still known today. However, some say that the tomb of Prophet Salih is in Yemen, and others believe it is in Jordan. According to Ibn Khaldun, Prophet Salih called his people to the religion of Allah for twenty years and he died at the age of fifty-eight.

The lands of the people of Thamud and the buildings they erected still have traces to this day. Western scholars have visited this place a lot. They have written about the remains of the Thamud people and the houses they carved from the rocky mountains. Among them is C.M. Daughty who wrote a book entitled Arabia Desserta.

When the Messenger of Allah passed through the villages of the people of Thamud on an expedition, namely Tabuk, he said to his companions:

"Do not enter the villages of those who have been punished except while weeping, and if you cannot weep, then do not enter their villages, lest you be afflicted with the same punishment that befell them." (Narrated by asy-Syaikhan from Ibn ‘Umar).

Their relics and traces are immortalized in the Qur'an to serve as a lesson. Many verses of the Qur'an instruct people to travel the earth, to observe the relics and traces of the people who have been destroyed by Allah, because of their disobedience to His commands, such as the people of Thamud. Indeed, Allah does good to all mankind, His punishment is severe and His mercy is great.
text.160:
In this verse, it is explained that the people of Prophet Lut denied the call of Prophet Lut, who was sent by Allah to them. Prophet Lut called upon them to be mindful of Allah, their Creator and Lord.

Prophet Lut was the son of Haran bin Terah, the brother of Prophet Ibrahim. Therefore, Lut was the nephew of Prophet Ibrahim. Lut believed in what his uncle, Ibrahim, conveyed, as mentioned in the word of Allah:

"So Lut believed him. [Ibrahim] said, "Indeed, I will emigrate to [the service of] my Lord. Indeed, He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise." (al-'Ankabut/29: 26).

Prophet Lut lived with Prophet Ibrahim in the city of Ur, then moved with him to Palestine and visited Egypt. From Egypt, he returned to Palestine with Ibrahim. They then separated, Prophet Lut went to Sodom, while Ibrahim remained in Palestine. The city of Sodom was located in the area of present-day Jordan, on the coast of Buhairah (Lake) Lut. Buhairah Lut is in the southern part of the Dead Sea. So the city of Sodom was not far from Baitul Makdis (Jerusalem). (See the vocabulary entry for "Lut").

text.165:
Prophet Lut warned his people, who were constantly engaging in homosexual acts and abandoning their wives. They committed these homosexual acts in public, in meeting places witnessed by many. Their actions were seen as encouraging others to do the same. Allah says:

And (mention, O Muhammad), Lot, when he said to his people, "Do you commit *fahisyah* (immoral acts) while you are seeing? Do you approach men with desire instead of women? Rather, you are a people behaving ignorantly." (an-Naml/27: 54-55).

Besides engaging in homosexuality, the people of Prophet Lut also robbed and plundered the wealth of passersby who were carrying merchandise.

The practice of same-sex relations (homosexuality and lesbianism) is strictly forbidden in Islam. This practice is very unhealthy. This deviant sexual behavior causes many new diseases, such as AIDS and herpes. These two diseases were unknown in previous generations. But now, both diseases have spread widely and rapidly.

Homosexual practices, in addition to other deviant sexual behaviors, such as changing partners or prostitution, are the most common ways of spreading the AIDS virus. This disease is mostly (90%) spread through deviant sexual behavior. Other ways of transmitting AIDS are through blood transfusions that have been contaminated with the AIDS virus and the use of non-sterile needles. Meanwhile, transmission from mother to fetus is not too great, namely below 10%.

In a hadith, Prophet Muhammad said:

"Zina (adultery/fornication) never appears among a people, so that they commit it openly, but they will be afflicted with contagious diseases and other diseases that did not exist in previous nations." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Ibn Umar)

From the hadith above, it can be understood that when humans begin to engage in abnormal sexual behavior, new diseases will emerge that have never existed before, and spread among mankind. Today, we are only beginning to understand what the hadith meant, which was spoken by Prophet Muhammad saw about 1400 years ago.

text.167: The people of Sodom did not heed the call of Prophet Lut (Lot), even threatening to kill and expel Lut and the believers from their land. Their immorality increased day by day, and they challenged Prophet Lut to bring about the punishment that he had threatened them with.
text.168: Prophet Lut (Lot) told his people that he disavowed their actions and deeply hated them. Prophet Lut was certain that any threat his people gave would not be able to harm him, because all of that was from Allah and by His will.
text.169: Prophet Lot prayed to Allah that he and his family be saved from the torment that would befall his people due to their vile deeds. He also pleaded to be kept away from Allah's punishment, both in this world and in the Hereafter.
text.170:
Allah granted Prophet Lut's prayer by bringing disaster upon his disbelieving people. Allah saved Lut and his family except for his disobedient wife. This verse does not explain the events that occurred before the calamity befell Prophet Lut's people. However, in another surah, it is explained that before the punishment came, Allah sent angels to Prophet Lut disguised as handsome young men to destroy them. Before coming to them, the angels first stopped at Ibrahim's house. Allah says:

He (Ibrahim) said, "Then what is your business [here], O messengers?" They said, "Indeed, we have been sent to a people who are criminals." (al-Hijr/15: 57-58).

After the angels in the form of handsome young men arrived at Prophet Lut's house, the people of Sodom came to his house. They intended to commit vile acts with Prophet Lut's guests. Prophet Lut tried to prevent them from doing so by offering his daughters (the women of the city) for them to marry. Prophet Lut said to them that his daughters were pure for them and he asked them not to touch his guests. Prophet Lut reproached them, saying that was there not a single sensible person among them. Allah says:

And his people came hastening to him, and before [this] they had been doing evil deeds. He said, "O my people, these are my daughters; they are purer for you. So fear Allah and do not disgrace me concerning my guests. Is there not among you a right-minded man?" (Hud/11: 78).

The people of Sodom rejected Prophet Lut's offer, saying that they had no desire whatsoever for his daughters. They remained defiant.

Then the angels introduced themselves to Prophet Lut and said that they were sent by Allah to destroy the disobedient people of Sodom. The people of Sodom would not be able to do anything to Prophet Lut.

When the people of Sodom attacked Prophet Lut's house, Allah made them unable to see Prophet Lut and the angels. Then Allah commanded Prophet Lut to leave the city of Sodom at night, along with his family, except for his wife because she would be destroyed with the people of Sodom.

Allah commanded that when leaving Sodom, none of them should look back. They then carried out the command. Allah says:

[The angels] said, "O Lut, indeed, we are messengers of your Lord; they will never reach you. So set out with your family during a portion of the night and let not any among you look back - except your wife. Indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Indeed, their appointment is [for] the morning. Is not the morning near?" (Hud/11: 81).

text.176:
This verse explains that the people of Madyan, also known as the tribe of Madyan, had denied the Prophet Shu'aib who called upon them to be mindful of Allah by carrying out His commands and abandoning His prohibitions. This verse explains that the actions of the people of Madyan were the same in law as denying the messengers, because denying one messenger is the same as denying all the messengers sent by Allah. According to Ibn Kathir, the people of Madyan and Aikah were one tribe. Only in the Qur'an are they sometimes expressed as the people of Madyan and sometimes referred to as the people of Aikah.

The tribe of Madyan was a tribe that inhabited the area around the Gulf of Aqabah and the area to its north. Madyan is the eponym of their ancestor, Madyan. Madyan was one of the sons of the Prophet Ibrahim. Their lives at that time were prosperous. They were happy and held positions as merchants. The largest city in the Madyan area was also named Madyan. This city is located in the middle of the Madyan area on the east coast of the Red Sea, in line with Tabuk. What is meant by the people of Aikah in the verse above is the people of Madyan.

Some commentators (mufasir) are of the opinion that the Prophet Shu'aib was sent after the Prophet Musa. Others say the opposite, namely before the sending of the Prophet Musa.

Shuaib called upon the people of Madyan, as the previous prophets had done. He explained to them that his task was not to seek wealth, power, or worldly gain. Therefore, he would not take payment from them for his call. His reward would be given by Allah who had sent him.

text.181: Besides associating partners with Allah, the people of Madyan also committed other sins and evils, including: 1. Decreasing weights and measures when selling and demanding more when buying. 2. Lowering the prices of goods so that they could buy those goods at very low prices. 3. Creating chaos and corruption on earth. This verse explains that Shu'aib called upon his people to stop the evil they were accustomed to doing. They were called upon to perfect the measures and weights both when selling and buying. Decreasing or increasing measures and weights is an act that harms others. This means creating corruption on earth. Shu'aib reminded his people that lawful wealth is better for them, because they were people of good livelihood. Allah says: "What remains with Allah is better for you, if you are believers. And I am not a guardian over you." (Hud/11: 86). What is meant by the remaining profit from Allah (baqiyyatullah) is the lawful profit in trade after perfecting measures and weights. Shu'aib reminded them that the evil deeds they were doing contradicted the provisions that Allah had established for all His creation. Therefore, they were asked to stop these actions and fear the punishment of Allah that would be inflicted upon those who commit evil. He is the One who created everything that exists, including them. He created them from non-existence to existence to bring about benefit on earth. Allah had created people who had strength and abilities that were stronger and greater than theirs, and who had more wealth and riches, such as the people of Hud, whom they had said were stronger and mightier than them. Because of the injustice and evil of those past nations, Allah punished them and inflicted great calamities upon them.

Decreasing or increasing measures and weights is an act that harms others. This means creating corruption on earth. Shu'aib reminded his people that lawful wealth is better for them, because they were people of good livelihood. Allah says: "What remains with Allah is better for you, if you are believers. And I am not a guardian over you." (Hud/11: 86). What is meant by the remaining profit from Allah (baqiyyatullah) is the lawful profit in trade after perfecting measures and weights. Shu'aib reminded them that the evil deeds they were doing contradicted the provisions established by Allah for all His creation. Therefore, they were asked to stop these actions and fear the punishment of Allah that would be inflicted upon those who commit evil. He is the One who created everything that exists, including them. He created them from non-existence to existence to bring about good on earth. Allah had created people who had strength and abilities stronger and greater than them, and who had more wealth and riches, such as the people of Hud, whom they once said were stronger and more powerful than them. Because of the injustice and evil of those past nations, Allah punished them and inflicted great calamities upon them.
text.185:
Even though Shu'aib had reminded his people, they remained in denial and disbelief. They even mocked Shu'aib and belittled the threat of Allah conveyed to them by stating that: firstly, Shu'aib was one of those bewitched, who said and did things only based on mere fantasies and imaginations. Shu'aib was an ordinary human being like them, possessing no advantages over them, and was even mentally unsound.

They rejected Shu'aib, and did not believe in the slightest that he was a messenger of Allah sent to them. Therefore, they denied Prophet Shu'aib, prevented others from approaching him, and threatened those who believed in him. However, Shu'aib continued to advise and remind them. Shu'aib was a prophet who was very clever at debating with his people. His arguments and proofs were very strong, so the commentators nicknamed him Khathib al-Anbiya' (the orator among the prophets).

Nevertheless, the people of Madyan remained defiant and rejected Shu'aib's call. Sometimes they said that they did not understand what he was saying, even though the call was clear and obvious. Sometimes they said that Shu'aib was weak, as if they thought that strength was the measure of truth and justice. Sometimes they threatened to kill Shu'aib, and expel his believing followers from the land if Shu'aib and the believers did not return to their religion.

Shu'aib's people also reminded the community that they would lose if they followed Shu'aib's religion because it forbade them from reducing measures and weights. They were amazed at Shu'aib who forbade them from worshiping the deities of their ancestors, and doing what they liked with their wealth. They criticized Shu'aib for the mistakes he had made. They mocked Shu'aib's prayers with cynicism. Allah says:

They said, "O Shu'aib, does your prayer command you that we should leave what our fathers worship or not manage our wealth as we please? Indeed, you are the one who is forbearing and right-minded." (Hud/11: 87).

They said, "O Shu'aib, we do not understand much of what you say, and indeed, we consider you among us to be weak. And if not for your family, we would have stoned you [to death]; and you are not to us one of influence." (Hud/11: 91).

Secondly, if Shu'aib was truly a prophet and messenger of Allah, then he was asked to bring down upon them (Shu'aib's people) lumps from the sky, as he had threatened. The attitude of Shu'aib's people was the same as the attitude of the Quraysh when they opposed the Prophet Muhammad, asking him to cause water to gush forth from the earth for them, to bring a beautiful garden and dates and grapes, to bring punishment by dropping pieces from the sky that would befall them, or to bring a house of gold and so on. (Read Surah al-Isra'/17: 90-93).

text.188: This verse is Shu'aib's response to the denial and challenge of his people, stating that he was not sent to make them believe by instilling faith into their hearts. Nor was he tasked with reckoning their deeds, punishing them, or inflicting torment upon them. His duty was only to convey the religion of Allah to his people. As for making someone believe, reckoning people's deeds, and inflicting torment, that is the right of Allah alone, because He is the Almighty and knows all the deeds of mankind better.
text.189: Because the people of Madyan remained defiant, Shu'aib threatened them by telling them to wait for the punishment that Allah would bring. At the time promised by Allah, a terrible disaster befell them. On that day, they felt an extremely suffocating heat. Nothing could help them from that situation, whether it was the shade of a house, or water to drink, and so on. Therefore, they went out into the open field and took shelter under a cooling cloud. In that state, Allah's punishment descended in the form of a powerful lightning strike that came out of the cloud, with a loud sound, and caused the earth to shake. They all died prostrate with their faces turned to the ground. Their condition was like the condition of the people of Prophet Saleh who were struck by Allah's punishment before. As for Prophet Shu'aib and the believers, Allah saved them from that punishment.
text.190: All the events found in the story of Shu'aib and his people, namely the destruction of the inhabitants of Madyan who denied Shu'aib's call and the salvation of the believers from the lightning strike and earthquake, are proof of Shu'aib's truthfulness as a messenger of Allah. Even so, the polytheists of Mecca and people who do not want to learn from it, still do not believe in the Prophet Muhammad.
text.191: This verse explains that God, who guides humanity to the right path, which can elevate humans to a noble and praiseworthy position, is the Most Just God, the Most Severe in His demands, and the Everlasting in His mercy towards those who believe.
text.192:
In these verses, it is explained that the Qur'an, which was revealed to Muhammad, is a holy book that originates from the Lord of the Universe. It was revealed to Muhammad gradually through Jibril (Gabriel), the angel tasked with bringing revelation to the messengers. The Qur'an was implanted into Muhammad's heart, meaning that the Qur'an was recited by Jibril in such a way that the Prophet Muhammad fully understood its meaning and intent. With such understanding and comprehension, the Prophet Muhammad could easily convey it to his people, and his people could easily accept it.

For example, when Surah al-An'am, which has 165 verses, and Surah Yusuf, which has 111 verses, were revealed all at once, the Messenger of Allah immediately received and memorized them. This is proof that the Qur'an was implanted into the Messenger's heart by the angel with his tongue.

Allah explains that the Qur'an was revealed in clear and eloquent Arabic with a beautiful style of language. Within it are also verses that challenge the polytheists of Mecca to create other verses like the verses of the Qur'an, if they do not believe that the Qur'an was revealed from Allah and is only Muhammad's creation. However, they were unable to match it, even by creating a single surah that was as eloquent and beautiful in its style of language as the Qur'an. Thus, there is no longer any reason for the polytheists of Mecca to say that the Qur'an is only Muhammad's creation. In short, even though the Qur'an was revealed in Arabic, which is their own language, they were unable to match its verses. If Muhammad could create the Qur'an, then logically, they could also create it, because they are both Arabs and both speak Arabic.

They understand the verses of the Qur'an, know the beauty of its style of language, and believe that the Qur'an does not originate from humans. They know very well the limits of human ability, yet they still refuse to believe in it because of the arrogance and denial that is deeply rooted in them.

text.196:
This verse explains that the Qur'an, which was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, was already alluded to in the books of Allah revealed to His previous messengers. In another verse, Allah says:

And [mention] when Jesus, the son of Mary, said, "O children of Israel, indeed I am the messenger of Allah to you, confirming what came before me of the Torah and bringing good tidings of a messenger to come after me, whose name is Ahmad (Muhammad)." (as-Saff/61: 6).

Besides the allusions to the revelation of the Qur'an in the books revealed to previous messengers, there were also prophecies about the sending of the Prophet Muhammad. Even though the current Torah has been tampered with by human hands, with additions, subtractions, and so on, there are still verses that explain the coming of the Prophet Muhammad as the last messenger and bringing a perfect Sharia. Allah says:

Those who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. So they who have believed in him, honored him, supported him and followed the light which was sent down with him - it is those who will be the successful. (al-A'raf/7: 157)
text.197:
This verse explains that in addition to being mentioned in the Torah and the Gospel, the coming and prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him) was also affirmed by the Jewish scholars who lived in Medina at that time. They said that there were actually indications or explanations about the Prophet Muhammad in the Torah and the Gospel. Therefore, many polytheists from Mecca went to Medina to meet with Jewish scholars to inquire about news concerning the Prophet Muhammad.

Ats-Tsa'labi narrates from Ibn 'Abbas that the polytheists of Mecca once sent envoys to Medina to meet with Jewish priests to ask for information about Muhammad. They replied, "This is the time of his coming," and they mentioned his characteristics.
text.198:
This verse explains that even though the proofs of Muhammad's prophethood have been explained in previous scriptures, and this is acknowledged by Jewish scholars, and known by the polytheists of Mecca from the Jewish leaders, those polytheists will not believe, no matter what book or holy scripture is presented to them. It is as if Allah is rebuking their attitude by saying, "We have revealed the Qur'an in clear Arabic with beautiful language to someone from the Arab nation, specifically from the influential Quraysh tribe in Mecca, and they have also learned about Muhammad's prophethood from the Jews in Medina, yet they still do not believe. So, even if the Qur'an were revealed to someone from a non-Arab group who is not proficient in Arabic, but by the will of Allah that person could recite it fluently to the polytheists of Mecca, they still would not believe in him. On the other hand, even if such an event were to occur, it would be an extraordinary event."

This verse is a consolation that can calm and soothe Muhammad's heart, which has been troubled by the attitude of the polytheists who constantly challenge and deny his call.

text.200:
This verse explains that Allah has instilled in the hearts of the disbelieving polytheists of Mecca the ability to understand the verses of the Qur'an and to feel the beauty of its language. Thus, they were convinced that the Qur'an came from God, not from human creation. However, they denied the Qur'an and rejected the prophet who brought it. Their denial became stronger, unshaken by anything. The desire to deny the Prophet and challenge him led them to commit sinful deeds, and they would only stop when the punishment had befallen them. In another verse, Allah says:

"And they rejected them [i.e., the signs] while their [inner] selves were convinced thereof, out of injustice and haughtiness. Then see how was the end of the corrupters." (an-Naml/27: 14).
text.201:

Thus, they were convinced that the Qur'an came from God, not from human creation. However, they denied the Qur'an and rejected the prophet who brought it. Their denial became stronger, unshaken by anything. The desire to deny the Prophet and challenge him led them to commit sinful deeds, and they would only stop when the punishment had befallen them. In another verse, Allah says:

And they rejected them, while in their hearts they were convinced of them, out of injustice and arrogance. Then see how was the end of those who caused corruption. (an-Naml/27: 14).
text.202: In such a state, without them realizing it, punishment came upon them suddenly and from an unknown source. Only then did they become aware of their actions all along. They complained and hoped that the arrival of the punishment would be postponed, so that they could perform righteous deeds, believe, and obey Allah and His Messenger. Even though they knew that the request would not be granted by Allah, they still tried to ask, just to reduce the pain of the punishment they were experiencing.
text.203: In such a state, without them realizing it, the punishment came upon them suddenly and unexpectedly. Only then did they become aware of their actions all along. They complained and hoped that the arrival of the punishment would be postponed, so that they could perform righteous deeds, believe, and obey Allah and His Messenger. Even though they knew that the request would not be granted by Allah, they still tried to ask, just to reduce the pain of the punishment they were experiencing.
text.204: This verse explains that the polytheists of Mecca once mocked the Prophet Muhammad by asking when the promised punishment would befall them. Their question was answered by Allah through this verse, saying, "Are they asking to hasten the coming of Our promised punishment?" Actually, they do not need to ask when the punishment that Allah has threatened will come. They only need to pay attention to the disasters that have befallen past peoples who denied the messengers sent by Allah to them. Even though those past peoples were mighty and had the ability to prosper their countries, not one of them was able to escape the punishment of Allah.
text.205:
Ibn Abi Hatim narrated a story about the *asbab nuzul* (circumstances of revelation) of this verse from Abu Yahdham, that the Messenger of Allah was seen in a state of confusion. The companions then asked him the reason for his confusion. The Messenger of Allah replied that he saw his enemies after his death from his own *ummah* (community), so verse 205 of Surah ash-Shu'ara' was revealed, and the Messenger's confusion finally disappeared.

Through these verses, Allah warns the polytheists of Mecca about His punishment by saying, "O polytheists, do you want to experience the fate that befell the previous *ummah*s? They were given the pleasures of life, physical strength, and the ability to prosper their lands. They thought that the happiness, prosperity, and power they obtained could save them from Allah's punishment. But that was not the case. They still felt a very painful punishment. So painful was the punishment that it was as if they had never felt happiness and pleasure in the world." Allah says:

On the Day they see it, it will be as though they had not remained [in the world] except for an afternoon or a morning. (an-Nazi'at/79: 46).

text.208:
This verse explains that Allah will not destroy a city or country except after sending messengers to them who convey good news, warnings, or promises, and threats. These messengers also deliver lessons to them and show the straight path to salvation and happiness. With the sending of these messengers, it means that Allah has shown compassion to His servants who are willing to follow the straight path that has been laid out. Those who reject the teachings of the messengers have wronged themselves and are willing to receive Allah's punishment. They are punished not because Allah is unjust to them, but because they deny the blessings that He has bestowed upon them by worshipping something other than Him. Allah says:

"And We never punish until We have sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15).

And the word of Allah:

"And never would your Lord destroy the cities until He had sent to their mother city a messenger reciting to them Our verses. And We were never to destroy the cities unless their people were wrongdoers." (al-Qasas/28: 59).
text.209:
This verse explains that Allah will not destroy a city or country except after sending messengers to them who deliver glad tidings, warnings, or promises, and threats. These messengers also convey lessons to them and show the straight path towards salvation and happiness. With the sending of these messengers, it means that Allah has shown compassion to His servants who are willing to follow the straight path that has been laid out. Those who reject the teachings of the messengers have wronged themselves and are willing to receive Allah's punishment. They are punished not because Allah is unjust to them, but because they deny the blessings that He has bestowed upon them by worshiping something other than Him. Allah says:

"And We never punish until We have sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15).

And Allah says:

"And never would your Lord destroy the cities until He had sent to their mother city a messenger reciting to them Our verses. And We were never to destroy the cities unless their people were wrongdoers." (al-Qasas/28: 59).
text.210:
This verse refutes the accusations of the polytheists of Mecca who said that the Prophet Muhammad was a sorcerer and a soothsayer. Allah states that the Qur'an is not a prophecy or magic originating from devils who receive and hear the words of angels when they are conveying Allah's revelation to the Messenger of Allah.

There are three things that show that the Qur'an does not originate from devils, namely:

1. The content of the Qur'an contradicts the will of devils. If devils strive to make people do deeds that will distance them from Allah's guidance, the Qur'an commands people to do good (ma'ruf) and prevent evil (mungkar).

2. The devils themselves do not want to accept the Qur'an, let alone convey it to others.

3. The devils are kept away from hearing the Qur'an that Angel Jibril conveys to Muhammad, or from listening to the Qur'an being recited by Allah's servants because the Qur'an is protected by Allah from devils.

text.213: This verse prohibits the Prophet Muhammad and his followers from worshipping gods other than Allah. They are commanded to worship the One God, sincere in obedience and submission to Him. Worshipping other gods alongside worshipping Allah is a cause for a person to be afflicted with the torment of hellfire.
text.214:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to convey the religion to his relatives, and to deliver Allah's promises and threats to those who deny and associate partners with Him.

Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, and other narrators from Abu Hurairah that he said, "When this verse was revealed, the Messenger of Allah then called the Quraysh to gather at Mount Safa. Some of them came themselves, and some sent their representatives. After gathering, the Messenger of Allah then gave a sermon, 'O Quraysh, save yourselves from the fire of Hell. Indeed, I have no power to harm or benefit you. O Bani Ka'ab bin Lu'ai, save yourselves from the fire of Hell, for indeed, I have no power to harm or benefit you. O Bani Qusai, save yourselves from the fire of Hell. Indeed, I have no power to harm or benefit you. O Bani Abdul Manaf, save yourselves from the fire of Hell. Indeed, I have no power to harm or benefit you, know that I can only maintain kinship with you in this world.'"

This verse was revealed at the beginning of the arrival of Islam, when the Prophet Muhammad began to carry out his da'wah. He was first commanded by Allah to call his closest family. After that, gradually calling the surrounding community, and finally to all mankind.
text.215:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to be friendly and humble towards those who had just believed and accepted his call, never to be arrogant, so that their hearts would be drawn in, a sense of affection among fellow believers would be woven, and they would also love him. Thus, da'wah should always be carried out with humility and good ethics. Allah says:

"So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you. So pardon them and ask forgiveness for them and consult them in the matter. And when you have decided, then rely upon Allah. Indeed, Allah loves those who rely [upon Him]." (ali 'Imran/3: 159)
text.216: Allah guided the Prophet Muhammad in carrying out his da'wah, which is that if close family and relatives do not heed his call, he should say to them that he disassociates himself from their disobedience and denial. Allah threatens their attitude and actions with a very painful torment as a recompense for their deeds. No one can escape the punishment of Allah on the Day of Judgment. Wealth, children, and family will no longer be of any use whatsoever in escaping the punishment of Allah. Only those who face Allah with faith and righteous deeds will be able to avoid the punishment of Allah.
text.217:
Then Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad, if he had carried out Allah's command to convey His religion to the people of Mecca, but they did not heed the call, then he should put his trust (tawakal) in Him and surrender all matters to Him. Only Allah is able to defend the Prophet from all the schemes of the enemy, and help him from all kinds of disasters that will befall him. Only Allah bestows mercy, and knows all the deeds and movements of His servants. Allah sees the Prophet when he performs the Tahajud prayer, bowing (ruku'), prostrating (sujud), and leading those who prostrate in prayer." The word "sujud" in this verse means those who pray. Allah calls those who pray as those who prostrate (sujud) to show that it is during prostration that a servant is closest to his Lord.

Allah explained to Prophet Muhammad that He is All-Hearing of all his speech and conversations, and All-Knowing of the Prophet's actions, whether he expresses them or not, and He knows all the contents of his heart. Allah is All-Powerful to give him recompense with the utmost justice.

text.221:
Allah explains the customs and beliefs of the Jahiliyyah Arabs in the form of a question to mankind so that they can judge by distinguishing between the truth of revelation and the falsehood of soothsayers. The question is: O mankind, shall I inform you of a news that, if you know it, will benefit you and purify your obedience and submission to Allah, in solving worldly problems, in distinguishing and judging the truth of Allah's saints and the friends of Satan, and to whom Satan returns repeatedly seeking and listening to a call for news?

Then Allah Himself answers that question by stating how the devils convey whispers to the soothsayers and how the soothsayers convey those whispers to the people who come to them, namely:

1. The devils come repeatedly to those who like to lie, deceive, commit many sins, and claim to be soothsayers. To them, the devil whispers meaningless thoughts and fantasies that generally do not correspond to reality.

2. The devil also whispers to the fortune tellers the information he seeks, then they convey it to the people who come to them as the result of their predictions. The results of these predictions are believed to be true by those who believe in them.

These verses seem to instruct humans to compare for themselves the process of delivering revelation to the Prophet Muhammad and its content with the process of delivering Satan's whispers to soothsayers, which they then convey to those who believe in the predictions. By comparing revelation and prediction, they will clearly see the difference.

Revelation is not just meaningless whispers, but is guidance for people who want to live happily in this world and the hereafter. The truth of revelation can be proven, both from the side of logic, noble character, and from the side of customs, while predictions are not. Predictions are not the same as correct reasoning, especially when viewed from the side of noble character and good customs. The one who delivers Allah's revelation is the Angel Jibril, and the recipient is the Prophet Muhammad, a trustworthy person known for his good character. As for the soothsayers, most are liars and deceivers, immoral, and disliked by society, claiming to be soothsayers after receiving whispers from the devil.

This verse rejects the claims of the polytheists of Mecca who accuse that the Qur'an revealed to the Prophet Muhammad is not something true, but comes from the whispers of the devil. Allah clears the good name of His Messenger from the various accusations they made up, by stating that the Qur'an revealed to Muhammad is Allah's revelation conveyed to him through the angel Jibril, not from the devil.

Going to fortune tellers is part of the customs and beliefs of the Jahiliyyah Arabs. Usually they go to fortune tellers to ask about something they do not yet know, such as about their future fate, the marriage of their daughters, estimates of the results of the business they will undertake, and so on. In addition, fortune tellers sometimes function as a physician who treats all kinds of diseases. What the fortune tellers predict is usually not true. If what is predicted actually happens, it is only a coincidence. The Messenger of Allah has warned that going to a fortune teller is a sin, as expressed in a hadith:

"Whoever goes to a fortune teller and asks him about something, his prayer will not be accepted for forty nights." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Safiyyah).

"Whoever goes to a fortune teller or a soothsayer, and he believes in what he says, then he has disbelieved in what was revealed to Muhammad." (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Hakim from Abu Hurairah)

text.224: This verse explains that the poets of that time were often followed by people who were misguided and deviated from the straight path, and inclined towards destructive actions. The followers of the Prophet Muhammad, however, were not like that. They performed many acts of worship, especially prayer (salat), and always maintained an attitude of asceticism (zuhud).
text.225:
This verse explains the misguided paths taken by poets in composing their poetry, namely:

1.  The poets create poetry without a clear purpose. Sometimes they praise something they once criticized, glorify something they once despised, and acknowledge something whose truth they once denied. This proves that their purpose in creating poetry is not to seek truth or state something that is true. In composing these poems, they only rely on imagination. The more imagination and fantasies they have, the better the poems they create. The misguidance of these poets is only followed by those who are also misguided, and will not be followed by those who like to seek the truth.

2.  The poets often say what they do not do. They encourage people to be generous and charitable, but they themselves are stingy and miserly. They often compose poems to offend the honor of others, such as criticizing, insulting, and so on, for a trivial reason. Conversely, they often glorify and praise someone for a trivial reason as well.

Such are the characteristics of poets who are criticized by Allah. However, there are also poets who are of good character and have extensive knowledge. Their poetry encourages others to do good and contains grains of wisdom, advice, and lessons. Among them is the poetry of Umayyah bin Abi as-salt, as follows:

From 'Amr bin asy-Syirid, from his father, who said, "One day I rode behind the Messenger of Allah, and he asked me, 'Do you memorize some verses of Umayyah bin Abi as-salt's poetry?' I replied, 'Yes.' The Messenger of Allah said, 'Recite it immediately.' So I recited one verse. The Messenger of Allah said, 'Recite it immediately.' So I recited another verse. The Messenger of Allah said, 'Continue.' I continued until a hundred verses." (Narrated by Muslim)

The Prophet's attitude towards Umayyah bin Abi as-salt's poetry shows that he liked poetry and poets, as long as the poet was a person of good character, with noble aspirations, and his poems contained many grains of wisdom. Unlike the poets and poems whose characteristics are mentioned in the previous verses (verses 221-226). It is such poets and poems that are criticized and forbidden by the Messenger of Allah.

text.227:
This verse explains that good and beneficial poetry and poets are those who possess the following characteristics:

1. Believe in Allah.

2. Perform righteous deeds.

3. Mention and glorify the name of Allah, thereby increasing the steadfastness of their faith in His greatness and oneness.

4. Encourage believers to strive (jihad), uphold the religion of Allah, and free themselves from the persecution of those who oppose them and His religion.

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari and Ibn Abi Shaybah that when the above verse was revealed, Hassan bin Thabit, 'Abdullah bin Rawahah, and Ka'ab bin Malik came to the Messenger of Allah. They were weeping and regretting their position as poets. Then the Messenger of Allah recited this verse (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 227) to them.

From the beginning of this surah, Allah has explained rational arguments about His power and greatness through the stories of the previous prophets with their people, which can comfort the Messenger of Allah who was troubled by the attitude of his people. These stories also explain the proofs of the truthfulness of the prophets He sent, the difference between soothsayers and the Messenger of Allah, comparing bad poets and poetry with praiseworthy poets and poetry. This surah concludes with a stern warning addressed to those who oppose the religion of Allah, that they will know their place of return, which is a hell whose torment is unimaginable.
